As I understand the matter any rotating mass can essentially behave like a gyroscope.

That may be why the tenure of stability vortices can sustain could be dependent upon the relationship between density for a fluid medium in which they are propagated and kinetic entropy inherent to it.

Because the rotating masses you employed in your experiment are initially propagated as lenticular discs in a fluid which are relatively stable, yet nonetheless undergo metamorphosis to become annular vortices consequent to collision, it seems to substantiate the likelihood that precession is involved.

That the aforementioned collision results in additional and evidently increasingly complex sequences of vortices may be instigated and/or amplified by slight cumulative increase to pressure and velocity for fluid present between the colliding vortices resulting in precession due to dynamic effects consequent to diametrically opposed impact of two relatively flat 'pseudo surfaces'.

If the centre of the disc shaped vortices were not the same thickness as their perimeter that could also result in additional lateral acceleration impinging upon intervening fluid and result in precession for the vortices.

It is possible resultant interactions between the fluid and the vortices may not be torque-free however because vectors for the initial vortices were juxtaposed on the axes aligned with direction of travel.

Evidently some effect imparts subsequent change, possibly due to lateral dissipation of the aforementioned pressure increase resulting in friction occurring between the intervening fluid acquiring a dynamic lateral vector and the vortices.

It would be very interesting to observe repetition for the experiment using fluids of varying density and propagation of vortices with diverse rotational characteristics such as two or more whirlpools emulating black holes, although that may only be possible subject to neutral gravity.

The patterns are as beautiful as they are fascinating!

Wondering if the reason of these secondary rings, at 90 degrees from the primary ring, is not actually related to the opposite of what your astronaut friend mentions.
Assuming we are looking along a longitudinal section of your experiment, X is the long axis, Y the up/down and Z the view direction: as the "high" pressure wave from the first ring spreads in YZ, it enters convection along the YZ plane (with pressure waves rotated around the X axis), local heterogeneities along the outside of the primary convection ring generate high pressure secondary waves along the periphery of the primary ring (so along the disk outlined by Y^2+Z^2=r ; r being the radius) and these collides with the primary high pressure wave (so you get two opposing high pressure wave along Y^2+Z^2=r ring plus 1 wave from the primary YZ plane) colliding. In this interpretation, my guess is that the energy between the 2 peripheral waves and the primary one are nearly equal so as to create a secondary vortex, so I would expect that we could mathematically tie together 1) the distance from the primary vortex initiation point to the secondary vortices initiation points, 2) the spacing between each secondary vortices, and 3) the energy dissipation along the primary vortex (so something to the power of 2 since it appears mostly 2 dimensional).
Would be curious to know your thoughts.

I think there is a low-pressure spot on each side of the opposing ring that creates an acting force to spin the mini rings 90.
Think of the low-pressure area following the smoke ring itself and those low-pressure areas carrying on and slipping past the crest of the pressured region of the ring. While doing so, the low-pressure areas momentarily layer on one another until collapsing into one low-pressure area. Thus, creating a slight spin due to one of the rings not perfectly matching up with the other and then the resulting low-pressure areas layering over each other as it crests over the region, and then said low-pressure areas snapping into one creating the 90 spin.

I don't feel that the outer segments turning 90 degrees then eliciting a ring per segment, is such a complex issue to comprehend...

The outward force of the main ring is stronger than the weaker force of that ring's expansion breaking it into smaller pieces...

therefore, assuming that's the case (as evidenced by the video) the continual lateral motion, the segments are now turning & expanding & turning into smaller rings because those are the only resistance points left while there's still enough motion of those parts.

Were this re-creatable at higher speeds, I feel that even those smaller rings would then split into multiple parts, then recreate the turn & ring process again, until all motion & thus resistance necessary & capable of eliciting that, ended.

If atomic particles are toroidal vortex rings in an aether medium then you can see how colliding atomic particle vortices makes other smaller atomic particle vortices... which are NOT constituent parts but energy reformed (conserved) into smaller vortices. When considering particle vortex theory you need to remember some important facts. Firstly the atomic particle vortex has a secondary plane of rotation - so it not only turns in on itself like these vortices but they also rim turn clockwise or counterclockwise - this differentiates between vortices making them either positive (charge) or negative (charge). So the difference between an electron vortex and a positron vortex is simply this secondary wheel rotation in relation to the primary inward rotation that creates the toroid. So if you want to model a particle vortex you have to add this secondary rotational phase either to the vortex as a whole or causing the toroidal element to twist slightly.  Secondly the aether medium in which atomic vortices exist is massless and can therefore move at the speed of light which is the speed of time and existence so thirdly the aether can move so quickly that it prevents an area of low pressure (or high pressure) from ever actually forming - so the pressure value of the aether can never change it is always constant even within a particle vortex. This gives the aether  a 'rigid' quality which allows it to carry waves which we know as the EMR spectrum and also gravity. But those potential waves (the movement of the aether)  move so quickly that they never actually change the pressure of the medium so never really exist unless they interact with a particle vortex. Magnetic fields are also toroidal vortices caused by the toroidal motion of the aether on large scales. This motion however does not seem to affect other magnetic fields... as the aether is massless it can move in two directions at the same time and pass through itself with out any effect, like two converging waves. The aether is not moving fast enough to interact with itself, but particle vortices are rotating at the speed of light which appears to change things and of course if you place a particle toroidal vortex with a magnetic field toroidal vortex the particle vortex is affected in its direction of travel.  If nothing moves fast enough it becomes something.

As an expert in fluid dynamics I'm sure you understand the importance of keeping the temperature identical in every area of fluid if you're looking to get near perfection.

So, having a lid, small contact thermometers on the sides at multiple locations on all sides would do wonders. Also room temperature control.

Your lighting rig (even LED is close) will give of a small amount of heat.

Obviously if temperature of the sides and top isn't completely uniform you're going to get convection that interferes with the fluid mechanic you want to see

Also putting fluid in your mouth isn't a good idea as it changes other variables from temperature to chemistry.

Finally lack of a lid will cause other minor chaotic issues for reasons other than air / water temperature differential.

Controlling the variables will take each iteration more time to set up, but I wager vastly less iterations, quality over quantity right :)

Finally: Congratulations on a great video

Hear me out... I've been watching and rewatching this trying to make it make sense. I have a theory.
We've got two simultaneous states of motion. (1) the two vortex rings moving towards one another (2) the subtle inward rotation of each ring themselves. SO by Newton's 3rd law we should get two equal and opposite reactions, which we do. (1) the rings colliding then expanding against one another (2) the secondary rings rotating in the opposite outward direction.

Seems to me the ink behaves the same at the ring's edge as it did at the nozzle. Friction carries the ink forward against the resistance of the static water, and so long as the rings have the angular momentum to gain traction on the water, they remain intact and burrow on. After impact, each ring takes over half the burrowing, the two colours together continuing until they lose the angular momentum to maintain cohesion, bloom, and are again inflated by the water dragged in the ink's wake, creating little rings. That's why the rings in the failed attempts sometimes swallow their partner : stronger angular momentum in one ring. For people more comfortable with a hands-on example : go buy and play with a water wiggler. Observing the interactions of the parts inside the wiggler, at different distances from the surface, can teach you this as well.

The concept is actually so simple. Force takes the easiest route out, which is sideways. Imagine water dripping on the floor. The simultaneous pressures from both sides create a imaginary wall,so there is only one direction to go. As the liquid moves along this wall, the friction gets less and less. Creating a rolling effect. Once the rolling motion overpowers the friction, smaller circles form again, 90 degrees off due to the motion caused.

I know how it makes rings. I think. Astronaut says it creates low pressure zones which suck the material away (can see arrows at 6:35) which also creates spots where the material is being pushed together on the other side. THIS force presses the two parallel lines of ink (if looking from side, ink looks like vertical lines) on both top and bottom, and the force of the two ink rings being shot into each other combined with the pressure on both the top and bottom of the parallel lines of ink results in smaller circles. In summary: the low pressure zones press the opposite sides together which creates two parallel lines of ink being pressed into each other from the outside, and on both top and bottom, resulting in smaller, broken up rings. Sorry if my analysis doesn't make sense but it really does in my head.

Hey Destin,

I'm not a scientist by any right, but I might have a viable theory as to why the smaller rings turned. If you've ever tried pushing an object that has a rounded edge, with another object with again a rounded edge, then you'll see that they tend to slide around one another. The best example I can think of would be pushing a small rubber ball into another small rubber ball, though theoretically when centered perfectly they would simply move in one direction, experimentally we know that it is nearly impossible to center anything perfectly. So, when this sort of experiment occurs, one of the balls will rotate around the other, so it will turn and move sideways. But what if the ball were cylindrical? But more like a penny than a Pringles container. If the rounded edge tends to rotate out of the way, that means that the flat edge would then be facing the pushing force directly, and flat objects don't tend to rotate when pushed by another flat object or force. In any case, this could be something, it could be nothing, but if you're still interested in figuring out why this works, maybe it is a hypothesis to look into.

Thanks for reading,

When the two ink bubbles collided the particles in them tried to move past each other. In doing so the particles from the two ink bubbles ended up by revolving around the point of their collision. So if I understand vortex ring formation correctly, it's when a fast moving liquid or gas interacts with a slow moving liquid or gas, dragging back the front faced material, and when it reaches the back of the fast moving material, it gets sucked back in, thus creating a ring. Everything that follows is based on that so if I'm mixed up there, I could be entirely wrong.

But their force looks redirected, aka the big ring that breaks up into nodules. Maybe the nodules form rings because the combined force from the two main entities colliding left them with the correct conditions to repeat the process.

The "mystery" lays in the tunnel that is within the ring, the ring tunnel has a pressure wave going through it, some points hit a zero tunnel width before other points and that defines the breakup points and the frequency of the wave when some points hit that mark determents the amount of those points with about equal spacing, turning the donut into many spheroids. since the collapsing tube collapses from both sides of each spheroid, this results in a net positive in momentum in one of the rotational directions. And creates an inner spheroid vortex with a low pressure zone in the middle. The outward direction of the initial 'collision' causes the low pressure zone to gain more momentum from the radially inward direction and is being pushes from a spheroid into a mushroom shape while the spheroid horizon is being inflated by the added pressure of the entering current. By that time much of the momentum has been canceled out and the footage ends.

Instead of coliding two rings you could collide a single ring into the center or the circular groundplate of a cylindrical tank, with enough initial momentum and a large enough diameter tank for the second ring to reach it's breaking point the effect could happen a second time. possibly recolliding it's breakup blobs with those of the rings next to it.

@smartereveryday You may not see this comment but I have a hypothesis on how it turns and faces the original ring. Now to test this theory I would need to go watch your 12 hours of footage and find every time it happens. But here it is.
I haven't watched the video that much and have just contemplated the idea so you have probably already thought through it. But even with a close to perfectly similar velocity of the shots, there is always one that is stronger than the other. That causes a whip around effet on the lesser of the two colors. At 6:38 the pink is the stronger and the blue is the lesser. This difference in the strengths causes a difference in the speed of the water as it rushes back in to fill the void left behind the secondary rings before they form. As you can see it turns 90 degrees before it turns into a secondary miniature ring. Now for the second part. Again nature doesn't like voids. So the bubbles of color that are about to turn into secondary rings are where water is having to replace the void the fastest. So now that it is slowing down the center of the bubble was where the strongest push was happening. So clear water rushes in pushing away the color that was previously in the middle and thus causing them to form rings. So my hypothesis is that the secondary rings are a result of the water rushing in to fill the void caused by the color taking up and leaving that zone.

So. at 6:38 based on my hypothesis. Because blue is the weaker of the two it is going to have a fast speed on the fringe of the ring. Meaning water will be rushing in from the pink side to replace the faster blue side turning the bubble where the blue is primarily on the outside and pink on the inside. Then once it has turned the water continues to fill the void left by the center and cause the color bubbles to be pushed out and into an almost perfect ring.

If I may I believe I can explain what is happening to give the cool effect and look. The water in the tank is completely stagnant. The colored water is being shot towards eachother, and when they make contact with eachother. There is still a small layer of stagnant water between the two forces moving towards eachother. As the pressure builds up in between the two forces it has to move somewhere. With it being water thats in the tank it keeps its electric charge with itself. So when it releases it causes the outer edge to break apart and the circles that for are from a low between the "explosion". If this experiment would be performed in a different fluid, had a waterfall making the tank water not stagnant, or environment I do not believe you would be able to replicate the result.

I think you have 2 toroidal vortices colliding, and because they're approaching each other, the rolling of the toruses is mirrored, and thus matches up, like friction gears, so they don't fight, but roll together away from the high pressure center of collision, creating that flattened ring, which, because it's pushing through more fluid on its way out, experiences turbulence, and destabilization, causing it to pull apart into pieces—in some manner related to how a splash starts as a kind of conic section, but water tension pulls it apart into evenly spaced spires and droplets—and then each of those is made of little, quasi-cylindrical sections of the two toruses, which are now like 2 sides of a toroidal vortex, still spinning so the insides push forward, and the outsides lag in the direction of travel, and a very thin layer of non-dyed water still being pulled in between these rollers keeps them separated (in many instances, maybe not all), allowing the centers to push apart from that high pressure system of the pushing-forward vortex middle, and the top and bottom to curl toward each other, and link up again, and then you have a bunch of little toroidal vortices heading 90° to the direction of the original parent, but still with all the same spinning. Of course, everything's getting more and more affected and turbulent by this point, so it gets really messy, and sometimes wisps of one color are peeled off, and shoot over the other color, and the toroids are all wobbly, and some fail to start.

Maybe, just maybe, the secondary rings are created just like the primary ring is created: When you shoot those... uhm... waves (?) out the syringes, they collide and create the primary ring perpendicular to the wave directions. My idea is that the low-pressure zones you were talking about at the end of the video pull in the surrounding water along the primary ring, and the in-flowing water -- just like the water from the syrringes -- creates more rings perpendicular to the flow direction, i.e. perpendicular to the primary ring.
If you scale up the experiment to create much larger primary rings, I can imagine two possible outcomes. Either the larger primary ring just decomposes into more small secondary rings than before, OR the larger primary ring creates secondary rings, which in turn create small tertiary rings.

Theory: The original collision spreads radial because that is the path of least resistance. However, the foreword momentum of those particles isn’t lost. So, when the path of least resistance is no longer radially outward from the original collision, the particles attempt to continue moving parallel to the original path. However, since more and more particles accumulate within this low pressure zone, the zone rapidly increases pressure until it implodes and creates the second rings. The rings are perpendicular to the original collision plane because they’re at farthest point their radial momentum could carry them. The implosion cannot create new momentum along the original collision plane or else the ring would continue radially in a strobing manner. Thus the momentum that is consolidated thanks the the implosion is dispersed in the direction of least resistance, which is perpendicular to the original collision’s plane.

The reason the implosion creates a second ring is due to the dynamic pressure in the center of the originally low pressure zone. The point with the lowest pressure will spike to a local high, before dispersing once again. However, just before it dispersed again it is still attracting particles, thus there is a evenly dispersed build up of kinetic and potential energy around the center point of the second ring that could be visualized as a sine wave.. maybe.

Visually we see the dye, however when two water slugs of equal/nearly equal proportions run into each other head on the moving fluid has to go somewhere.  It turns 90° or close to 90° depending on the delta in each water slug proportions.  Since the slugs can’t be 100% identical and the tank can’t be 100% steady state, there will always be slight variations in the pressure at the convergence edge of the 2 colliding water slugs.  These inconsistencies create secondary vortexes.  The math probably assumes a perfect system, it doesn’t account for the minor variances of water temperature, salinity, currents or variances in the speed, size and angle of the water slugs themselves.  so the math models failed.

I believe I know what is happening here and why your rings split at 90* angles. The vortex is created due to an injection of flow into a standing medium and friction from the standing medium induces the flow to rotate. This is why the vortex rotates the way it does forward in the center and reversed on the outside. The vortex also creates a low pressure zone just behind it pulling the medium with it. By aiming the two vortexes at each other you are trapping them in a single standing wave of sorts. As the pressure waves move towards each other they create a high pressure zone between the vortexes that expands the rings while halting their forward momentum. perturbations in the flow of the medium escaping from in between the two planes strengthen the vortexes in some places and begin to create nodes in the vortex. When the pressure differential equalizes is when your ringlets are formed and I think they are formed by the same process that formed your original vortex. The medium following the nodes is moving faster than the surrounding medium. When the vortexes collapse the momentum trapped in the wake of the more powerful nodes continues and pushes forward. The remaining pressure differentials found in the wake of these nodes cause a small puff of flow into the standing medium which creates your ringlets at 90* from the wave propagation. You can actually see the reversal of the standing wave at 6:28 as the rings starts to pull back in the weaker flow zones while the nodes continue forward now sucking up dye from the weaker zones and collecting dye from the center of the disk towards the wake of the stronger nodes. Looking at the node most inline with the center at 6:45 you can see that the nodes are no longer rotating with the vortexes but are now moving forward as a single flow and by 6:46 that flow has propagated into its own new vortex powered by the mass following the node. Or at least that is what I see happening. I would love to hear your thoughts on this.

The initial jet is drawn into a torrid by drag with the surrounding static fluid, then that combined energy can only expand outward, enlarging the ring and as you demonstrated, the ring reaches a "snapping point" where the arms of each segment snap back to each one's center. The overall velocity is still outward but each segment is now its own outward jet, moving through the surrounding still fluid, so it must form a similar torrid. NOW, consider if EACH 2nd series vortex expanded until it snap-segmented, resulting in a 3rd series of vortexes, and they generated 4th series, and so on with each set, dividing the initial energy into rings moving outward 90 degrees off axis from its parent event . . . . mind blowing!

The reason it turns into a perfect ring or bullseye pattern seems very simple to me.
The dye at the outermost edge of the expansion has more resistance it has to push through undisturbed water. The dye behind it is essentailly following in it's slipstream which allows it to catch up and build up at the front.

Then as the ring expands it gets thinner and thinner until it has to break up and the dye prefers to clump together just like water in air tends to.

Presumably the secondary clumps form a ring for the reason the original ring forms. I wonder if on a massive scale you would see tertiary rings 😮

Theory for the secondary motion rings...

The most basic explaination for the experiment is shoot colored air bubble at other colored air bubble underwater.

So when the 2 weighted air bubbles collide they don't combine until the motion momentum in the "equal or opposite forces applied upon" is so perfect they cancel each other out without combining.

The problem is why does the secondary motion picture at the end of the first collision . i think it is because once the air has moved its full forward motion the laws of vaccume under pressure take effect and in the instiant the forward momentum stops and the bubbles begin to recoil they come into an equal air mass and mix as they expand to fill available fluid space. And when those points touch and bind they vaccine "pop" secondary ring pulses as result of the union of 2 seperate massez

I think I might have an idea as to where you might find answers. These phenomenon aren't unlike the things I research related to pulsed electrical currents of extremely short impulse duration (less than 1ms) generated by disruptive discharge. I've recently been studying Electric Double layer Capacitors, then electric double layers in plasma, and that lead me to discover Birkeland current-- which is identical to the type of motion in the subsidiary rings produced in these collisions. Notice how the small ring is turning in on itself, but the electrical conditions of charge separation due to ionization produces an 'orbiting' spiral chasing around the ring... at least, I think this is the summary of the case.
I admit, I only just fell onto these connections tonight, but my research in pulsed currents clearly relates, so I knew the significance it should hold is great. The only other such research I had done about the natural curl of smoke rings produced by opposing forces was this video; hence, I wanted to share my findings with you immediately! I'd love to stay in contact, but I know you are busy; still, my offer stands! If I come to understand this better, I will leave my conclusions in these comments.

So if, for example, the pigment in one color weighed more than that in the other it would affect the outcome and prevent symmetrical contact. But changing the temperature, and thus the water density, of the whole set-up might also affect the geometry of the outcome. Is the number of right-angle circles always the same?

One issue I would ask if y'all considered is the compression of the clear water in the boundary layer between the two spheroids. It looks to me like that would be the fastest moving part of the contact zone, which would create a low-pressure area that is inherently unstable as it is both spreading out and having to expand radially. I would bet that the water in that boundary layer resists slowing, which would tend to thin the boundary layer. But it would be very difficult to maintain a laminar flow that is radially uniform. That is stream of consciousness, so it may not make sense.

6:50 that's not a mystery, it is infact far from a mystery. That is a result of two opposing forces colliding in a open space. A moving object is not willing to change it's velocity itself, there needs to be somekind of force doing that. That's the reason why they fluids want to travel straight before they collide. You can think about it like a ball traveling in a vacuum without any forces impacting it. The ball will continue traveling endlessly in one direction. The reason why that's not possible over water, is that the density of the water is higher, which means that objects float more easily in water than in air, which means that they won't reach the ground as fast (in short terms, even though the force of the gravity is the same in both water and air, the forces applying aren't the same) . In air, eventually everything falls too fast for anything to float.
This is a really cool vape trick

the thickness of the ink plays a factor into the situation. After the collision the material is thin out causing water (being malleable) to try and reconnect with itself. As the material thins out from the collision the pressure of the water trying to reform on itself separates and pushes the out ring from the center ring. The existing force of being pushed outward is then applied to the 2 separate dies. Starting a secondary collision of miniature rings being formed. The 90 degree turn of the ring is the momentum caused from the outwards force.

There were these sets of "challenges" for you to complete, and when I was very little my siblings had completed all of them. I was always persistent when I really wanted something, but I think this time what I wanted wasn't so much as to get the achievement, just to prove I could if I really wanted to. I'm not sure if it changed their perception of me, but it probably changed my perception of me.

My best bet is it’s a constructive wave pattern thing with or something. The plasmas collide at different speed and energy, with equal mass, and react in a way I would vaguely compare to a water droplet.

^
|
|
I have a feeling that if I looked up how the water droplet science worked, it would work like that.

OBSERVATIONS:

The plasma balls have to be equal mass when they collide, but don’t need to be going at the same speed or energy, necessarily.

When the plasmas are shot through the water, they will act as a wave would work. The plasma is moving against and around the water, and when the two collide, they will essentially push the water passing around them into the center of the force, and spread out to form a ring.

Their individual waves, like I said before, interfere (add on top at different speeds/energys) with each other and set a NEW wave pattern to create circles. The collision cause them to split the circle into individual, fairly evenly spaced, wave patterns. When this ring starts to make the little rings, it thins out the bigger it gets. That means these uneven waves will split apart the ring where the waves are weak, and the reaction will make the stronger waves sustain their structure with the water and create little, evenly spaced balls of plasma to spread out. They will react like a water droplet, as the wave’s energy sucks the matter in with its current, and roll outwards until they lose speed against the force of the water.

and density of the plasma could play a good role too in how it travels thru the water in a solid form, kinda how it thinly spreads and lingers in the water the way it does. Also note that the plasmas do not mix, and there is water spaced in between them to separate. This happens most likely because of density, and gives a good layer of structure around the plasmas.

I hope you didn't waste time trying to figure out how the little rings at the end are formed, especially, as you mentioned in the video, turning sideways. It's about the simplest answer in the world -> fluid dynamics. The Coriolis Effect... as fluid is pulled into a vacuum it moves toward the center bending to the right. When fluid is pushed from a high pressure it moves outward bending to the right. This is how we find high and low pressure zones in the atmosphere taking shape. So if you picture, as you said, the low pressure zones in the big outer ring pulled the ring apart into segments, and zoom into 1 such segment, the center of it is the point of lowest pressure, pulling the fluid from either side in. This draws in from opposing directions but due to the Coriolis Effect each side bends to it's respective right hand side. This results in a swirling motion around the center. The orientation of what is top, bottom, left and right is based on fluid dynamics also. The water outside the rings is relatively stable, unmoving, creating a ceiling. In fluid dynamics the lowest pressure is where the fluid is moving the fastest. Conversely, the highest pressure is where the fluid is moving the slowest. So stable water is like a virtual wall, in this case ceiling. The outward force of the large inner circle expending is a higher pressure zone because it's pushing outward from the center, effectively creating a floor. So given the orientation of ceiling and floor, you can logically deduce what is left and right relative to the moving fluid in the zone between them... Effectively forcing the small rings to rotate perpendicular.

It turns 90 degrees because of the outward force that's still technically being applied from the collision itself. Well, technically speaking they aren't actually turning 90 degrees at all but rather reforming into new rings.


How it works is that the pressure exerted creates a swelling of nearly equal pressure around the collision. Those lower pressure spots begin to form in an almost perfectly symmetrical ring around the collision. However, even after the nodules have begun to form, there are still "streams" of pressure pushing outward from the collision through the center of the nodules, forming smaller rings perpendicular to the collision.


The streams exist because even though you're paying attention to the dyed liquid, you're not giving much thought to the water being pulled behind it. You're still focused on the collision itself.

Beautiful! Also intriguing, I imagine, to mathematicians and physicists as well as engineers and inventors. I'm particularly intrigued by Arnold Anderson's suggestion that your experiments might generate only prime nos. of secondary vortices. Your work reminds me  of the work of my father (Winfield W. Salisbury, 1903-1999), who was all four of the things I just mentioned (though math was of interest only sofar as it served the other three). He told me once-<del>maybe he tried this; I never did-</del> that if you have a big barrel open at one end, and fasten inside it a closed cylinder, concentric to the barrel, then whack the back of the barrel, you can create an (invisible) vortex of air that can knock someone down 10 or 20 (or more?) feet away. Dad worked on two big ideas in his later life: fusion power, and gravity. He had, at my count, 6 or 7 ideas (each better than the last) to make fusion a usable energy source. The last one he called "spiral fusion." Apparently he figured out how to make a ball-lightning generator (he surmised, or calculated, I don't know which, that "ball" lightning [a misnomer] can be modeled by a new solution to Maxwell's equations); the balls created are actually toroids or vortices. His scheme, basically, was to generate two charged vortices of deuterium/lithium plasma, spinning in opposite orientations (one clockwise, one anticlockwise) and slam them together with enough energy to start fusion; of course everything would be very tightly and strongly controlled by ultrastrong magnetic fields so that 1) the vortices or toroids would move very fast and with very precise aim, and 2) the energy released by fusion could be contained and channeled to do work. Though his early efforts in this arena became concrete first at Zenith Radio in the '50s, then at Occidental Petroleum in the '70s, neither those nor later such projects were carried to completion. If you're intrigued enough by this account to look into his work, you could check out two articles about gravity he published in "Nature," on 11/22/69, describing a lab experiment to generate gravity waves; and sometime in January 1974, in which he proved, from Special Relativity and using elementary math, the existence of a secondary gravitational field (analogous to magnetic fielda as a secondary to electric fielda), repulsive in this thought experiment, which he dubbed the "gyron" field or force. For reasons that still baffle me, the latter article attracted very little notice, and that, from experts in General Relativity, negative. A broader account of Dad's work can be found on the website of Southwest Museum of Engineering, Communications and Computation (SMECC).

Not going to waste my time watching a 12-hour video of the troublesome job of making fluid vortex rings collide head-on in a glass enclosure, I would simply point out that the direction of the fluidic flow in those vortices is poloidal, and when they collide head-on, the fluidic flow is now outward along a perpendicular plane, so those new vortex rings are generated as compressed fluid from the two original tori are escaping from the circular periphery of the decomposing tori, in the same manner as they might be generated by fluid ejected from a circular tube opening, (however, it is now axisymmetric, limited to the pressure from within the original tori, and rapidly decomposes). See: Monika Nitsche's "Scaling properties of vortex ring formation at a circular tube opening." Physics of Fluids, v. 8 no. 7, July 1996, 1848-1855.

I have an idea on why the secondary rings face out (if you can follow):

The vortex rings, if you take a cross section, are rotating, so if you measure the motion of a point on the inside, it goes forwards, out, backwards, and back in. When the two rings combine and the dye clumps up in those "nodules," the "forward and out" motion pulls dye from the center of the nodule outwards and starts the motion pattern of another ring.

Hey, Destin. I can see what's happening in this one. When two vortices of opposite rotation come together, they attract each other and annihilate, because the vorticity will sum to zero. Once the rotation stops, there is nothing but a low pressure center without motion, and so at that point, it radiates outward like a regular pressure wave. It is easiest to see with a surface vortex (two whirpools). When opposite whirlpools come together, they annihilate and it radiates outward as a travelling surface wave. The whirlpools are non-dissipative waves, and the travelling surface wave is a dissipative wave. The vortex rings in this cool video are annihilating just like whirlpools annihilate on the surface.

A vortex has a center line called the vortex axis or vortex core. Right at the axis, rotational velocity is very great. A whirpool has a vortex axis that ends above the water. A vortex ring has a vortex axis that makes a complete circle, (ring). The rotational motion is about that ring. If you examine a small volume right at the vortex axis, you will see that the ring is being stretched outward by that rotation. The fluid is still rotating about the ring axis, as they meet (because angular momentum is conserved for each ring). So the fluid in the middle of the rings is pushing against the fluid from the opposite ring, and also rotating about the ring axis, and so the net motion is outward. As the ring stretches outward, the angular velocity around the axis goes way way up, just like a tornado angular velocity goes way up when it is pulled upward, or a button on a string toy goes fast when it is pulled tight.

Then the cool part happens when the vortex axes actually meet. When they are very close, there is an attractive force between the axes. They are rotating like matching gears. Fluid right that is rotating one axis can just as easily rotate around the other. Right when that happens, it is just like the whirlpools on the surface. Fluid crosses over between the vortex axes and the rotation sums to zero and you get a radiant pressure wave outward. But right at the boundary where those ring axes are meeting, you will find that there is an outward flow right between them, right at the line where they touch, and an inward flow on the far sides. And so there is a rotation about a new axis, of exactly the same type that created the original vortices.

Now the obvious question is why it breaks up into rings, because it would appear to have symmetry at the boundary. So you would naturally ask why it wouldn't continue to spread outward without breaking up. My first though when I saw it was that I was looking at a quantization. There were already present on the rings secondary waves called Kelvin waves that transverse the rings, that were not very easy to see at first. When they came together, those Kelvin waves were superimposed and there was an interference pattern between them. The constructive peaks of that interference pattern formed the places where the axis first merged, and the troughs of that pattern formed the places where it merged more slowly. And so the inward and outward flow at the boundary was broken up in such a way that at periodic intervals, there was also a small inward flow at the inside of the boundary. When that inward flow became sufficiently large, that forms a complete toroid of flow (a new vortex ring). But that doesn't happen immediately. The spreading of the ring has to reach a certain distance. I am guessing that distance is the point at which the interference pattern of the Kelvin waves is close in size to the rotation about the vortex axes.

Theory: As the clear fluid is displaced and moving outward it both condenses but then stretches and breaks into balls, the colored fluid moving outward with greater force (since it is the pusher not pushee) wraps around it, making the outward facing rings that are colored outside and clear inside like a donut. I think of it like if you had a bunch of people standing in a circle doing nothing in white jackets and a bunch of people rushed in wearing colored jackets from the left and right.  they would 'push' the white jackets out from the center, and as the colored jackets rebounded off eachother in the center and pushed out themselves from the center their speed would be greater than that of the white jackets. The white jackets would also then bump into other white jackets around them, clustering together (from being pushed together) and the colored jackets would eventually outpace them and run/wrap around the clusters of the white jackets. This would create then white jackets in balls/clusters and colored jackets rushing around them on either side. If we do this in 3 dimensions with fluid it creates these donuts. THat's my theory on this.

Angular momentum is angular momentum, I guess! It has to go somewhere. As a disc golfer, I understand that if a rotating disc hits something, it's angular momentum has a significant impact on the direction of the resulting trajectory. Discs often do very weird things if they hit at low angles. Head-on, they simply tend to drop, and don't deviate much compared to if they weren't rotating - because all the energy is dissipated forward into the solid object, rather than being deflected.

In your beautiful experiment here, what we're seeing is the total angular momentum being preserved beyond the head-on collision, because there is no solid object for that energy to dissipate into. It is retained in the new 2-part disc until the expansion speed drops to a point where the angular momentum can express itself again - as it no longer feels like a head-on collision.

What I want to see is how much rotation each part of the 2-part disc has - because it seems to me that the collision forms two counter-rotating discs with a static boundary layer between them, and it's this counter rotation which triggers the formation of the multiple vortexes perpendicular to the disc which formed them.

If each side of the 2-part disc spun the same way, then we'd simply see an expanding disc.

It must be the interaction of the static boundary layer, the counter-rotating discs, and the velocity of the fluids, and the viscosity of them that are the controls.

I could explain why the rings form from the geometrical standpoint. I guess both "shots" really have to be balanced to have as similar properties as possible for the rings to occur. It is like this little rippling occurs at the outer rings as their velocity gets pushed out but some of it more at the back side still has a little velocity of moving forward and creates these (5:16) imbalances of the outer circles where periodically yellow pushes over blue or blue pushes over the yellow edge. And when rings get too big, the 2 bigger circles collapse and since blue and yellow volumes move at the same pace it is easiest to form a new stable geometry (a circle) from blue and yellow each other. And the interlinking of these little circles happens at the points where these (5:16) imbalances occurred which makes half of the circle one colour and another half the other colour.

The generated secondary vortex rings appear to be similar to aircraft contrail looping (search Youtube for examples).  In both cases there are two parallel vortices, curved in this case and straight in contrails.  Small perturbations along the rings lead to larger instabilities which eventually pinch and bring the vortices closer together and eventually joining to form smaller vortex rings.  For the most part, vorticity conservation is maintained where the sum of the vorticity of the small rings is very close to the vorticity of the two original rings.   Some vorticity is extracted through turbulence which is the cascade of the seemingly larger swirls breaking into smaller swirls.   I think the small scale instabilities I referred to could be replicated with steady state fluid equations and small scale linear secondary perturbations that are time dependent.  These equations could show the of bringing the parallel vortices closer together at regular intervals.  However, nonliterary comes into play in the pinching and joining into the smaller rings.  If this hasn't been done already, this could be the basis of a master theses research.

Before collision, each vortex does not change size due to the their equal friction with the surrounding air on all sides of the vortex ring. But when they collide, there is much less friction in front of each vortex because the air is moving in the same direction as the other vortex. This leaves only the air friction, or viscosity, behind and on the sides of the vortices. The air on the outside and inside of the rings are moving in opposite directions and so the friction will not affect movement of the rings. But each vortex's air is moving inward from the rear point of view. The friction of this inward moving air with the still air behind them then causes both vortices to spread outwards due to Newton's third law.

The answer of how the secondary ring turns 90 degrees to the primary ring is simple, it is carrying the inertia of the collapsing material from both side and while being pushed outwards, gravity of the high pressure areas is bringing the two parts into one another, blasting in the only low pressure area left: 90 degrees outwards, away from the primary ring. It is a fractal of the first in mathematical terms, and can be mapped out in sets scaled to the primary ring's initial dimensions.

The membrane stretches outwards until there's not enough of the colored fluid, then it starts to implode by having low pressure zones along the perimeter, which creates the secondary rings (since the fluid has an initial speed and is trying to stop). Now the secondary rings are spinning (that's just what rings do), and you'd think they should keep moving perpendicular to the radius of the initial big membrane, but remember that the mini rings are still moving outwards from the initial impact. So the rings take the path of least resistance and the 2 movements merge into that spinning outwards one, and that's why they rotate 90 degrees. They "go with the flow".

This is off topic but I thought it might be cool if you could experiment with this idea and make video about it so here it is. I have an idea for a lifting force machine.
Step 1: Get hollowed out cube.
Step 2: Securely attach magnet to inner bottom of hollowed out cube.
Step 3: Place a lever on inside bottom of cube behind the magnet thats securely attached to inside bottom of cube so that one side of the lever is pointing towards you and hanging over the magnet.
Step 4: Attach a vertical bar to the top side of the part of the lever that is not hanging over magnet witch is securely attached to inner bottom of cube. Make sure the bar goes all the way up to the inner top of the cube barley touching it.
Step 5: Securely attach a magnet to the side of the lever that is hanging over the magnet that is attached to the inner botttom of cube.
Note: Magnets need to be facing each other with attracting poles N,S or S,N
Note: The lever is going to have to be realy close to the magnet on inner bottom of cube because of how close those magnetic fields need to be to interact. But not so close that magnets can touch.
The magnet on top connected to lever is pulling the magnet on inner bottom of cube towards it and since the magnet on inner bottom of cube is connected to cube, this pulling force acts as a lifting force. Now at the same time the magnet on inner bottom of cube is pulling the magnet on top downwards BUT the magnet on top is connected to the lever so any downwards pulling force is being converted mechanicaly by the lever into upwards lifting force. Now if you know anything about magnets you now that there are magnets powerfull enough to lift far more weight then just there own. So essentialy this divice is exploiting the powerfull pulling force of magnets by mechanicaly transforming its magnetic pulling force into mechanical lifting force through the clever utilization of a lever, and walla stuff can be made to fly. Imagine if the magnets in this experiment where electro magnets so the ammount of electrical current going into them determined the ammount of lifting force that it would have. Now imagine this system being used as an attachment that could be placed under or ontop of vehicles to counter the weight of the vehicle and any cargo its carying. Now imagine  if this was done with powerfull permanent magnets and turned sideways and placed in an electric generator and had enough strength to pass through the magnetic fields as it propelled itself forwards with its own magnetic pulling force.     Signed   AMA

So those 90 degree ones .. it's like squeezing a baloon through hand when the pressure compresses one side, and the air gets squeezed to the other side where it's easier to flow to. Think of it like a ring, made of same stuff(water) but a sort of separate due to particles moving in ring form, more like a solid object would have (splitting the particles at the tip, moving them-in this case pulling- along the surface and behind it) till it reaches low pressure point and gets sucked back in), so the ring goes out and stretches, untill it reaches the point in which it's internal resistance (swirling water) is too weak to still be the ring (the resistance of water is causing the ring to deform into blobs, cause it's easier for spinning water to sort withold it's movement along the deformation than keep pushing the water around), so the blob deformation builds up as the particles tend to make their movement easier, so to say. It breaks up in the weakest positions in which (due to pressure and movement -> blob deformation) the moving water was squeezed out like half of baloon in the hand. The rotational movement and still water pressure are both pulling around and squeezing in underneath the previously broken ring part into basically a miniature atomic mushroom cloud donut... made of water.
This is my viewpoint on what happens :P I stay by it. Especially the mushroom cloud thing :D

Or a container in which there's a ball (building up spinning movement of particles of water) in the middle, and a rubber sheet dividing it into two parts - representing the resistance force of still water. As it's becomes pressurised (or vacuumed) on one side the sheet collapses around the ball, and since it's water and movement we're speaking of - the place where it "closes around" the ball would be a point of sucking the water in (low pressure + movement). So it's like the ring of water have it's own surface tension due to the nature of it's internal movement.

Awesome video and excellent dedication!  I believe the reason the primary ring splits into multiple smaller clusters, turn 90 degrees, and reform into smaller rings... is actually very simple.  It all has to do with the marrying of the vortex waves.  Due to the Path of Least Resistance, the two initial stage vortex clusters are propelled outwards with roughly the same inertia due to the symmetry of the experiment. Since both pumps (and I'm assuming this) push the ink cluster forward they leave the component at quite likely a clockwise rotation.  If however you could force one cluster to leave at a counter clockwise rotation of the same velocity the result would mirror and quite likely not turn 90 degrees and expand in to smaller rings as witnessed.  However, since (again my belief) both vortex waves approach each other in line (but not in true balance) the result is the expansion forward as the primary ring expands and the residual waves comingle, gather, and then due to the inertia of the primary ring they have no option but expand one more time in to infinity as there is nothing more to effect the dynamic of the wave.

While playing with water in a sink, I like to create a vortex while I drain it. It's quite mind numbing to watch the water spin with constant speed. It doesn't speed up or slow down once the vortex is created. The rotation of the earth plays a huge part in it. While making a vortex in the opposite direction adds a bit of chaos. It doesn't want to keep the shape but the motion of the water holds its form. The other day I tried something. Before creating the whirl pool I pulled the plug. The water was still as it drained. Now I know the water does spin down drains even in the smallest amount, there is motion. As the water drained I did two quick motions. Down and to the right. That was enough to create a vortex with the remaining water. It took me by surprise that it didn't take much to create one.

With that, the low pressure from both directions meeting at the high pressure with the rotation of the earth may be playing a role in the video. Nature loves reminding us on how little we know.

I think I can see why it does what it do
What:
1) There are circles created at equal intervals and
2) Why the circles form 90 degrees from impact.

Why:
1) When I saw the original footage it looks like the two vortexes create sine waves with each as if they are equal yet opposite in frequency and amplitude, which would make sense if they are equal in force and volume yet spinning in opposite directions. Some of the circles in some of the experiments where not equally spaced, but my guess is that although force or volume applied to both vortexes was not completely identical, they were close enough to create "beats" in the "frequency" of the collision.

2) Each vortex has multiple forces working on it, it is spinning while moving forward, so its makeup is constantly being thrown outward and being cycled back in (from what my high school diploma remembers). And that when both vortexes hit each other, they lose all their forward momentum and rotational momentum from impact with each other, but still would both have outward momentum that would be amplified by both (maybe?)

again my only physics background is high school, I'm not trying to be some know-it-all, its just what I think and see.

I feel as though i'm simply repeating what other people have probably said at this point and i'm no way an expert.
TL:DR Bernoulli's principle, cavitation-like effects.
The two Dye vortexes when fired at each other with nearly identical speed, low enough to maintain laminar flow, while also within range of hitting each other and aimed with nearly perfectly mirrored vectors will collide with each other and act as the others normal force, with the following mass that wasn't immediately countered maintaining its momentum and travelling in the path of least resistance, being in a ring formed perpendicular to the angle of collision.
The next part as to the secondaries I believe being that as this ring travels through the fluid and spreads out, due to Bernoulli's principle its speed creates a slightly lower pressure ring that under the nearly perfect conditions you created breaks up into points of evenly spaced lower pressure depending on the exact rays of direction with the most energy after impact. as these points draw the fluid, including the dye into itself until its pressure under the effects of its speed match the pressure of the stationary fluid around it and as it slows down due to resistance it becomes a point of now higher pressure and acts much like a cavitation wave expanding again and now with that minor amount of angular momentum in addition to its previous forward momentum becomes another ring.

Im not very educated in physics or anything and this is just a guess cuz i have no idea but here it goes .As the fluid is pushing through a hole and into the open area filled with mass of a little less density the differences in pressure along with the shape and rim of the exit point causes the vortex. If The density of the water in the tank is less than that of the ink solution in the injectors then with the right burst of pressure the turning of fluid in the ring will happen at higher velocity. Iv done this with smoke rings. The fluid is constantly turning inside out like if you were to attach a tornado end to end, until the pressure equalizes and the vortex loses its velocity and form. When two vortexes colide the mass in between is ejected outwards and repeats the vortex process all over again using the remaining enertia and velocity from the original two. But this time the pressurized fluid is expanding outward in the form of a ring and not exiting a hole. If the colision is close enough to perfectly aligned and the velocity is stil strong enough, then the pressure of the fluid between will be forced out creating a negative pressure that tears the two rings apart while at the same time joining the two together as long as the velocities are the same. Thats why the secondaries are half one color and half the other, and also why they arent perfect circles. The velocities of turning fluid are changed or unmatched and so the secondaries are unstable. But mabe thats just from breaking apart? Mabe if they could maintain the velosity and not slow down and dissipate they would eventualy equalize, stabilize,  and blend? You first must try to understand how smoke rings are created. As the outer ring spreads out and seperates, the small blobs have velocity and ar pushing their way through stationary fluid. Because the path around the major accelerated mass is longer than remaining stationary, it creates a low pressure area around the outside of the blob, pulling it apart much like the outer initial ring. Now that the blob is pulled outward by low pressure, and the low prssure behind the blob welcomes the fresh non dyed fluid around the back, much like the low pressure spot behind a big rig on the freeway, it rotationally accelerates the dye around its radius and forms a ring..

So there is low pressure around the outside,low pressure behind, fluid friction which rotates the fluid perpendicular to direction of travel, this allows food to come through the back and accelerate around the outside of the newly-formed donut and you have a ring. What exactly causes the initial ring to break up into smaller blobs at equal intervals is more puzzling to me then how the secondary rings are formed.

Re: how/why do the secondary rings turn 90 degrees after breaking away from the primary ring...

My suggestion is that there appears to be a rotational movement of the primary ring (caused by the slightly unequal collision of the two colored rings). The rotation isn’t from the center of the primary ring, but rather as the primary expands the edge of the “donut” rotates on its axis. (Take a chocolate topped donut, cut a slice of the donut’s ring and then rotate it so the chocolate topping ends up on the table).

This rotation (of the entire outside edge of the primary ring) has a gyroscopic effect on the secondary ringlets, which causes a 90• rotation.

There is a lot going on for sure, but focusing on the 90 degree rotation, it appears to me that the main cause is by the severing of a vortex line and having it join with the vortex line of the opposing torus. When a vortex line is severed, it doesn't like ending in a fluid and will twist from torque and angular momentum like forces. It's only hope of becoming stable again is to find another vortex line to join up with. When the collision is symmetrical(spatially and net force) the opposite rotation of each torus allows the severed vortex line from each torus to line up with each other and become one. The 90 degree turn with a laminar secondary is the result of the vortex lines rejoining quickly. Turbulent secondaries seem to be caused when the vortex lines dance around each other, but can't join up. You can predict early on where the "secondaries" will form by looking for where the outer "torque" layer begins to flow over the opposing torus. Its cool to see a broken vortex line from a red torus can join with a broken vortex line from a blue torus to make a new vortex line to create a "secondary" with colors from both torus. But, I think it is more interesting at 6:47:27 on the 12hr cut, where it seems the vortex lines appear to resist being torn, and instead knots are formed instead of secondary torus.

the 90 degree change in the orientation is actually really simple. The two rings are moving in mirrored directions. when they collide they are in balance as they expand outward. eventually the vortexes fragment from slight imbalances/turbulence etc. and at that point the swirling fragments of each of the opposite rings are more stable if they connect with one another, and they will tend to do this. The tips at each end unite creating little rings of turbulence that are at a 90 degree angle from the original.

Any fluid shooting in a direction inside another fluid not moving will be held back by friction of the non moving fluid and cause a turbulence that will spin back on itself. This causes the further branching which causes the same effect to happen as before but since this time the particles are now moving at 90 degrees the rings also will be at 90 degrees. The branches remember are shooting in straight lines again and get dragged through friction and create more rings. That's at least what it looks like to me. Equal amount of kinetic force leads to both waves treating the other as a solid obstacle due to resonance, dissipating their energy into sidewards expansion. The expansion leads to pressure changes (everything moving is describable in a wavelike function through time), thus you have peak densities at which rotational forces occur due to them being the most energy efficient way to let energy dissipate in a closed environment. So you get the membrane formation when the waves interfere with each other, expansion until forward directional movement has largely been converted. But at that point we've only accounted for directional movement not rotational movement (vortexes are rotating outward) so we can consider the expansion to actually accentuate the rotation, as well as the rotation of both vortexes complementing each other. But at some point the remaining energy isn't enough to overcome friction by itself after the initial expansion stages, so what happens is a separation into low pressure and high pressure on the basis of the remaining velocity of the initial wave. That's what causes the initial outer ring to split along with some mechanics of waves traveling through fluids that holds some areas of the fluid together better than others, on the edges we actually have 2 opposite sides correctly rotating, simply the separation of low and high pressure areas is enough to get the low pressure areas into rotational movement through friction. That's how I'd explain it :D

I know nothing about fluid dynamics, but my intuition tells me the following about the 90 degree secondary rings:

1. As the original rings collide, they "smush" together, flattening and forcing their energy/material outwards as the resultant system expands.
2. The resultant local velocity of the material is in an outward direction from the center of the circle, traveling into calm water.
3. The calm water doesn't want to move (inertia) and resists the movement, providing a sort of friction impeding the motion of the outward traveling expanding ring, causing the rotational moment necessary to help formulate the new rings.

the 90 degrees turned little circles are not that complicated to understand. the red and blue ink have velocity, right? they keep pushing against each other, hence the outward motion of the big ring. but they keep pushing against each other. and because nature is never 100% accurate they dont push in all places with the same force. so at some point the blue and red ring break each other up into the little parts and they start circling around each other, like clouds do.

That is easy, the ink on both sides are radiating center out away from each other... when the equal bloobs at equal velocity meet in the middle they spread, that rotating lip continues to spread. While the ink on the rim continues to rotate on both sides away from each other... of course there is a little bit of clear water between the 2 ink layers. Then there is a certain point where the amount of ink remaining reduces and the the rotation from both rotating mushroom rings grab onto each other on that edge and suck up the remaining edges into newly formed rings. the physics come from the combining forces of the original larger rotating ring forces meeting at the seam, when the ink runs too low to continue to maintain the original velocity.

Are the secondary rings not caused simply by the fluid resistance at the perimeter of the two opposing waves?
So, the friction at the outside of the ink jet globules is drawn back into the globules at the rear, while intertia draws the main mass of the globules forward. When they collide, their equal energies are forced outward, perpendicular to the direction of the two masses, where there is less energy/pressure. Latent mass follows the initial collision, expanding the disc. At the perimeter of the disc, there is resistance that sweeps around it and is drawn to the lower-pressure areas toward the centre of the disc at either side of it, causing rotation. I would imagine at the perimeter of the secondary rings are smaller tertiary rings, and so-forth, provided you can produce a large and accurate -enough collision.
As for the equidistance of the ssecondary rings, a larger sample size of varying volumes of ink might identify a variable or constant that is fundamental to the equation, maybe count the number of secondary rings and compare it to the circumference of the primary ring. Also see if the outcome changes with the velocity of the ink jets.

I can see the rings remain apart while stretching outward and the spinning tubes briefly attach and each form one half of the toroid when spun outward. The main driving force of the rings is the moving columns of water coming out of the holes. when the rings move outward being stretched, the moving columns of water are now moving outward which is what forms the new rings. so now there are a multiple of "holes" and columns of water instead of the original two starting holes and columns. The columns are the streams moving outward and through the centers of the toroids.  Like rip currents or jet streams and low pressure tubes which create tornadoes, the two streams get stretched out and fractal into a ratio of streams.

Big Mahalos Destin! Fascinated by toroidal vortices since learning & perfecting "bubble rings" to kill time during decompression dives 30 years ago. My guess is the secondary rings form at the moment momentum decreases enough for ambient water pressure to overwhelm the expanding 360 degree "bow wave". Get the initial impact just right (4 years it took!) - the expanding, still micro-counter-roatating ring (fluid discs??) must break into uniform satellite vortices. This is where it gets fuzzy for me but consider the following 2 strange phenomena I've observed with my own rings:
If you blow a ring & then gently touch it with your finger you will break it's perfect uniform tension, instantly separating at that point into two receding "tails" twisting to a point like rolling bread dough as they race in opposite directions to the opposite side of the ring where a catastrophic failure occurs in a mass of bubbles. I suggest something similar takes place on each side of your secondary rings in the tank. Perhaps, the obvious component is drag vs diminishing momentum.
The second phenomenon I'll throw in for fun & more head scratching. The trick is elusive & difficult to reproduce in open water. But the bottom of a calm swimming pool is best.:

If you blow two perfect rings in quick succession the second one will overtake the first. Then something magical happens. The overtaking ring uniformly compresses in diameter in the toroidal wake of the first ring, then rapidly accelerates passing clean through the first. If the pool is deep enough the first ring then becomes the pursuer and will repeat the process. Enjoy the thought! Aloha

That is really cool, and I love the lessons on persistence. While there are many that I could think of on a daily life standpoint that I can improve upon. However, for anyone interested in reading this, the one thing to me that I see as my "Vortex Ring Collision" is my book(s). I am an aspiring writer, and back in high school, say 10 years ago, I stumbled upon a very cool idea for a story. It started as a simple frame by frame drawing of a fight that intrigued all of my fellow students during a Study Period, and morphed into a full fledged comic book. Everything was there, the plot, the conflict, the characters, everything. There was one problem, I'm terrible at drawing, and I felt that my mediocre stick figures wasn't doing my story justice and I lost my motivation to continue. I made several attempts to go around this problem, like trying to find someone who could do the drawing, or improving my own art, but to no avail. Then, I remember in college reading my first Tom Clancy novel, "The Hunt for Red October", and thinking "Wow, you can actually picture in your head how he wants the readers to imagine the action that is going on". It was the first time I really experienced something like this and it demanded my attention. I was still scared of going back to this original story idea because it had developed at this point from a hobby to almost an obsession, piecing together parts of this book and its characters to the finest details I could come up with, and writing them all down in a notebook, knowing perfectly well that I may never actually use them. So, I wanted to test my newfound platform of storytelling, and made a couple of fan fictions. I went with games I enjoyed playing, like Mass Effect, which I made a 50 page short story on, and Borderlands, which went from a short story idea to a 300 page fan fiction. From my friends and family, the stories were a success. However, the original story idea was still a much bigger project and I was again still scared of not being able to do my story justice. Then, about a year and a half ago, I met a new friend, who thought a lot like me, and I shared my book idea with him. I told him what it looked like when it started, and how much it changed over the years. To my surprise, the story was not done changing. I had discovered, with my new friend, an entirely different angle to tell the story, in such a way that I never before imagined, and thought "This could work. I can actually do this." Now, a year and a half later, and while yes I have had a couple of hiatuses in writing this book, whether it be from writers block, or from other things happening in my life, I am roughly 250 pages into my first book, and I have a total of at least 10 books planned out for this series. The story is ever expanding, with my friend and I constantly bouncing ideas off of each other and improving upon it. At this point, the story has transformed from a hobby, to my life's work, and it is a constant struggle to make sure it is the best I can make it to be, but I can't wait to see it all come to fruition and if I ever can, to show my story to the world, or to at least anyone willing to read it. Thank you for anyone willing to read my little tangent here, I know, this may have not been the video to post such a thing in, but his lesson on persistence really resonated with me and I thought that I would share.

The smaller rings at 90d make perfect sense to me. Both rings are going towards eachother pulling more air/water through their middles to keep the rings curling back on itself and travelling forwards. The air/water inside the ring then pushes the rings to expand when they collide, as there is more pressure in the middle and less on the outside of the rings (the 90d). As the rings expand and fight the rotation of the other ring,  the sides - where those gaps appear between rings - of the rings pull/whip together and form smaller rings. 2 parallel lines of spinning fluid don't travel in parallel for long. I can visualize how the fluid moves, but it's hard to explain in writing.

Hey Destin!
Loved this video... I can't give you the mathematics on the problem, but I'd like to take a stab at the solution. To me, this starts with the toroidal vortices that are sent to impact each other. In order for the vortex to be propelled forward in a fluid, it must spin "inside out". Both sides are doing the same. At the point of impact (assuming they hit just right as you painstakingly know) each side attempts to roll away from the collision.... so far so good, but when the ring gets too large for the ink to hold together, it tears into smaller sections, and because of the higher density of the ink vs. water, they connect all the while continuing to move away from each other, creating the new, smaller toroidal vortices we see around the former site of contact.... Does this make sense? Please write to me if you see this note. Thanks!

Regarding colliding toroidal structures: See TRISOPS, a nuclear fusion experiment at the Univ of Miami, in the 60's & 70's. Dr Wells originated the investigation. The collision of toroidal plasma structures produced shapes that were quite similar to the those in your video, including numerous radial toroidal vortices. I was not involved in the experiments, but saw the impressive apparatus.

This is very very astounding phenomenon!! I can totally understand what you or your team are stuck into this for three years.

My personal explanation is, when first two rings collides, the coming water will keep pushing them. Thus they end up to be the flat plate. But they can't keep being larger forever, they will meet a critical point that the plate can't maintain its shape and break apart ( same phenomenon happens when you squish a clay ball really hard, perimeter will break at several parts after a well.) Just like the clay ball, the break point (attaining critical attraction) will start at several points, then between each break points, there forms several segments between two break point. After breaking, each segments start to contract (like rubber ring), and ends up with each segments (curved, not straight, since perimeter of the original plate is curved) contracting to its center. Finally forms the secondary ring.

If above process make sense, some further experiment can be thought of. Number of break points happen on the plate may depends on the size and speed of the coloured rings, which may depend on distance, pumping speed, ...or other possible factors. And the angle of the curved segments approximately antiproportional to number of break points. So by adjusting the angle of the segments.
1. If the angle of the segments is really large, the secondary ring may not appear, or appear in a strange manner.
2. If the angle of the segments is really small, the curved segments are approximately straight lines. And the same phenomenon may occur on the contracting straight lines. In the other word, there may possibly be third rings appearing??

Nothing above is experimentally supported. Everything is my imagination.

Awesome experiment!  This reminded me of when I was doing personal research with Chaos theory.  I wrote several computer programs to play around with the ideas.  Chaos theory can inform our understanding of turbulence and might be an interesting next step in understanding this phenomenon.  As I was exploring the landscape of the math I found that there are more than simple bifurcations in the numbers.  I found splits at every integer up to 36 and there were patterns of even longer sequences.  There were even bifurcations in places that were I would not have thought to find any.  I have concluded that there is no such thing as random but randomness is the name we give to complexity that we have not yet decoded.  Count the vortex rings as if they are fractals and see if they match with any chaotic patterns.
I feel like this could have some vast implications in the world of physics, quantum physics and astronomy. Maybe, just maybe, the way a multiverse is created.

So, what I think is happening:

This isn't just two wave fronts colliding, it's two wave fronts colliding with a stationary front. If you watch some of the footage in the middle, you can see a cushion of colorless water getting compressed by the red and blue water.

As the fronts expand they take this cushion with them. You can see not only concentric waves as the fronts expand, but also radial waves. As a result, this forms cone shaped "still water" that is getting forced in the direction of the expansion.

At some point, the compression wave forces the colorless water out of the ring of colored water in a direction orthogonal to the original colored waves.

These act like radial jets squirting colorless water through the colored water, creating a circular perturbation that changes the direction of those rings.

BTW, I suspect the effect you seek to achieve can only be done when everything - and I do mean everything - that affects the rings must be identical. That includes the effects resulting from rings' characteristics such as density, surface tension, and velocity. The fluid medium, in this case water, must be perfectly still, at a uniform temperature, with the same characteristics that control the ink. The velocity of the rings likely have a great effect on the shapes observed.
