As to the 'how do the secondary rings move 90 degrees (to the initial collision)' question: There appear to be two principles at work when this happens. Directional motion (force) moving radially from the center of the initial collision (along the Z axis) and the result of that radial motion (force) on the fluid in ITS path to either side of that radial motion/force (along the Y axis).

Unless ALL of the fluid in the tank is totally motionless (and I mean TOTALLY), then as the result of the initial radial collision force, ONE side of that Z axis is going to have a differential lateral (perpendicular) force/pressure compared to the opposing side, irrespective of how little (or 'immeasurable' that force (pressure) may be).

The combination of the lateral force with the differential 'splitting' lateral (perpendicular) force creates a compound or secondary collision where the primary (initial) radial force is greater that the secondary (lateral/perpendicular) force (because it came first and therefore has more inertia) and this 'force ratio/relationship' necessarily causes the 'nodes' (caused by the initial collision & radial spread) to turn 90 degrees because of the greater force of the initial radial momentum to the lesser 'split' (lateral/perpendicular) force/momentum.

You've got a kind of initial 'vortex spin' that, while still spinning, gets tossed sideways as the greater force of the initial collision 'splits' the fluid to the side as the large ring expands, so the 'spinning' node turns sideways along the same axis as the direction of the expanding initial collision. Since nature ALWAYS moves in vortexes (and never in a straight line), as long as there is sufficient motion/force and momentum, new stages of vortexes 'rings' will continue to appear, 90 degrees to the axis from which they are generated. If this attempt at a description of my theory can be followed, I'd like to hear your thoughts on it.

Additionally, it doesn't appear that the INITIAL collision is between two vortices, but between two linear expulsions of ink in water; i.e. no vortex is generated by the plunger or the orifices from which the ink emerges. It appears that vortices only emerge from the resulting collision radially from 90 degrees off the Z axis).

The sequence of directional force is #1: X axis (blue and red ink moving towards each other), and then Y & Z axes simultaneously (creating the 360 degree ring expanding out 90 degrees from the initial X axis collision.

The secondary 'rings' (actually vortices) form at 90 degrees to the initial collision along the X axis because the force of the initial collision is greater than the force of the secondary collision of the initial ring with the surrounding (relatively 'static') fluid.

The secondary vertices are at a 09 degree angle from the original one. Of course!!! The reason seems obvious. When the two original vertices collide, (say along the X axis), the collision creates a circular shockwave in the YZ plane. At 90 degrees. Then the secondary vertices are created along this ring expanding in the YZ plane, and if you would trace the motion of their "centers" they would all converge to the original point of collision of the two original vertices. Hence the pattern you filmed.

Mystery 90 degree "turn"? Hardly. You smash two things together and the only place to go is outwards, you see this by the initial collision. the smaller rings creating at the outer perimeter aren't turned 90 degrees, they're created at a perpendicular to the initial movement due to the impact and outward spreading of the two larger objects. The rings are both created and moved 90 degrees offset from the original collision. You can see this very clearly at 6:50. High pressure moves to low pressure "bubble", bubble is created, bubble is then morphed into ring due to outward movement (high pressure moving through the center of the low pressure bubble). The last ring which appears to "turn" is literally the same movement/creation as the origin of the larger vortex ring to begin with. Change the vector, you change the orientation of the ring. Since the vector is now from the center to the edge, the ring is thus facing the exterior. Do vortex's move laterally? No, they move in the orientation of the movement of air (or water), which is blown through the middle.

I wish we could have talked 4 years ago, because I've seen the same phenomenon in a different setting.

Specifically, at the Experimental Aircraft convention at Oshkosh, when Lyle Sanders is doing very large loops in his Sea Fury with smoke generators on his wingtips. (This was years ago- I'm not sure if anyone is doing it now.)

The spinning tip vortex generated under high G entrains the smoke and you get very high angular velocity tubes of rotating smoke...but the real interesting phenomena occur nearly a MILE behind the airplane: the two counter-rotating tubes of smoke merge...turn 90 degrees...and then break into two lateral tubes that separate, giving a chain of smoke rings where before there were only two parallel tubes of spinning smoke.

That's what you have when the two vortices collide- if you look at the outer edge, it consists of two parallel spinning tubes- contra-rotating- that again- can only merge to produce an additional spinning region 90 degrees to the original tubes. In your case they expand outward due to the hydraulic push of the center being flooded from the initial squirt. You don't get that extra "shove" in the flight-generated scenario.

Bottom line is, there is another place to see what is essentially the same vortex merge/break behavior. I knew what it was at the time but no one seemed to care when I pointed it out, but I knew a fluid dynamicist ought to see it. Unfortunately, all the ones I knew were so full of themselves that you couldn't talk to them.

After watching and stopping the video many times, I have formed a hypothesis for the origin of the secondary vortices. I believe the seeds of the secondary vortices reside in the original toroidal projectiles. Take notice of several details. As soon as the toruses collide there begin to form spokes as the two mushroom clouds expand against each other. This suggests imbalances in the original toruses, which, because they collide slightly off balance, cause the roots of spinning. As the spokes expand you begin to see vortex shedding even before the secondary vortices organize (This is most notable in the yellow and blue end-on view). Also, notice that at the moment the secondary vortices begin to form the two colors are initially separate and on the same side as the torus from which they originated. I think that this fact suggests that the outward expansion is more powerful and quicker than the spin caused by the spokes (original imbalances). As to the number and distance from center of the secondary vortices, I think these give evidence of the density and viscosity of fluid medium. The spokes reach a critical point where their internal spin predominates over the outward push of the ink (similar to a bowling ball slowing forward motion so that the spin allows it to grip the floor and curve as it approaches the pins). This is the point when the secondary vortices form.
I would predict if the fluid were less dense and/or less viscous, the vortices would form closer (and sooner) to the center of collision, and they would be fewer in number. Conversely, a more viscous and/or more dense fluid would result in more vortices and a greater distance from the center.
The one question I could not answer from the video because of the quickness of the process (slower motion could solve this problem) was the direction of spin of the secondary vortices. Was it one direction only, or both, or random? Are there clues in the spokes for which way they will spin? Are all of the vortices in a given trial spinning the same direction, alternating direction, or random?
In conclusion, I have provided a hypothesis for the source of the secondary vortices, a way to test the hypothesis, and further questions about the nature of the vortices. What questions or comments do you have for clarification and discussion?

This is a very inspiring video to me. Many years ago I first tried a program called logisim, which if you know don't know is a logic circuit simulator, lots of fun, very educational, I highly suggest trying it. But anyways, ever since trying that I've had this idea in my head that I want to make my own breadboard computer out of logic chips and discrete components etc. I knew nothing about computer science or electrical engineering at the time and the idea always sorta stayed on the backburner because of that. But 6 months ago or so I started learning electronics and though I'm still a very long way from building a computer, reaching that goal is actually something that seems doable now. I have a lot of fun experimenting with electronics and learning new things and watching/reading things on the topic to learn more. It's been a really fulfilling journey. I guess the moral of the story is don't be afraid to go out there and do something you've always wanted to do. You have nothing to lose. In my case the "lab" I built cost no more than maybe a couple hundred dollars, since most chips and components are dirt cheap. The hardest part for me was probably just getting started and learning what exactly I needed and where the best place was to get it. After that it was just a matter of buying what I could and learning how to use it. Best of luck to you all. Cheers.

Congrats and thanks for sharing. This was REALLY cool to observe. My take on the low pressure zones is that once they meet and equalize, that cancellation creates another (breifly existing) low pressure zone. As the ring expands outward, those equalized nodal points cause a drag where the colored fluid draws back into the low pressure spot and turns the flow inside out, thus the 90 degree flip.

I don’t want to say I understand the other rings decisions on how they “turn” 90° but I have a theory. As you showed, the pressure of it collapsing brought them to a single point and at that point they had too much mass in one spot so it had to go somewhere. It couldn’t go back up unless it was moving outwards, which it was so it did. But this isn’t all. It couldn’t stay in it’s original orientation because the pressure of it moving out kept it from expanding that way so it had to move to it’s side which is my explanation for why it looks like it rotated 90°.

The outward initial disk destabilizes at the outermost edge where its circumference collapses into a sine wave shape (probably caused by small perturbations in the initial condition). Thus, the peaks of that sine wave are "jets" with slightly higher velocity than the valleys, and this leads to the formation of little "mushroom" vortices oriented along the outward radial axis (in a cylindrical coordinate system). You'll even notice that the little rings inside those vortices remain half colored red-blue on their respective side, but there is some turbulent mixing. Mystery solved! Would be cool to see what it looks like if it remained in the laminar regime at the end.
-Dr. Dunn

After watching the collision at the beginning of the video, my explanation is pretty straight forward. Two identical orbs of fluid move towards each other at the same speed and rotate opposite of eachother, like gears. When they collide, the orbs flatten out onto each other and as the pancake gets flatter and wider, the edge is slightly thicker than the "connection" between there and the center. So the connection will at some point break and the ring along the outside still had the same friction of moving against each other. As it widens there isn't enough fluid to keep it a ring either because the fluid membrane popped or the ring doesn't supply it, and it separates almost perfectly because the orbs impacting was almost perfect. That results in multiple rotating masses along a perpendicular axis and the velocity of it results in the rings until those too pop from lack of tension.

The middle of the pancake however is more complex. One guess is that the fluid masses impacted and had more "back and forth" fluid movement and friction than "side to side", therefore keeping more fluid in the middle as the outer ring simply impacted and most every bit of its momentum shot perpendicular. And of course that ring pulls needed fluid from the central vibrating orb until it becomes too weak to support itself.

I'll watch the rest of the video to see your explanation now and see how my prediction compared

Why it turns 90 degrees and forms rings. The point at which the expansion of the ring slows to a pace that can't support the big vortical ring is called the "termination shock" and the remaining outward pressure seems to puff the nodules into mini rings. If you think about it, there's no way other than smaller rings for that transfer of momentum. The low pressure nodules still have rotation left that can't form a large double ring where the old large ring was, so the path of least resistance is to form smaller, lower energy vortices. Great video! Here's my theory:

Precession. Fluid vortices like these generate centrifugal force (with respect to the molecular bonds) at the points where the outer ring begins to decay into low- and high-pressure zones. Those zones start to spin, generating a small centrifugal force, but there's still outward flow from The initial impact. The nodes then turn 90 degrees because that outward force is putting a load on the spinning node, causing a precessionary tilt. This is also why the secondary rings all turn the same direction.

The 90-degree transform occurs at the impact, right? The collision forces the ink samples to move in the vertical plane instead of the horizontal one. As the samples travel outward they, I'm guessing, rotate at opposite angles. As the rings approach one another the wake they create causes their opposing ink sample to buckle around and loop back.

The rings are rotated 90-degrees because the ink vortexes collide along the same axis. I'd bet there's a way to make rings at other angles which result in different ring rotations... What if they collide at a 90 degree angle to begin with?

I can't do the math, but I can tell you what's happening. The water with the dye in it has a different melecular bond strength than the water around it (that's why it's sinking, you changed its structure to reflect a certain wavelength). When the ring gets big enough, it stretches till the bonds break, and the snapping of the dyed fluid rushing back towards itself causes the fluid to rotate and form a ring. The rings then rotate 90° out because as the fluid starts spinning, the law of conservation of angular momentum take over, which states that whatever energy is put into a spinning entity will take effect on that entity ~90° out from the input

You can see that as the large ring separates into the smaller individual clusters (which seem to be a small scale version of the large vortex collision) they're are still under the outward-spreading forces of the two fluids colliding causing the clusters to spiral out at a 90 degree angle.

I don’t know if this has been said, but what would happen if you turned the experiment vertical? With one shooting up and the other shooting down? Or, what if you aligned it with North/South, or East/West? The reason I’m saying this is that it may be caused by gyroscopy, the rotation of the Earth. After all, that’s what causes vortexes in hurricanes, and tornadoes are known to spin off the edges of hurricanes. And water going down a drain spins one way in the Northern Hemisphere, and the other in the Southern Hemisphere. So the rotation of the earth does have some effect on even very small vortexes. It would be awesome to recreate this experiment in the Space Station, removing gravity from the equation could give sharper results?  Whatever the cause is, it is very fascinating!

I'm pretty much a nobody in this sphere of fluid dynamics (although I do have a BSME) but here's my input; as Don Pettit (sp?) states, there's a low pressure area that causes the pulling and separation - but why.  Well, I think you have to start at the beginning: there's velocity at play as the dye liquid was originally propelled from the cylinder.  We need to consider the way it was propelled - it was pushed through a cylinder.  So fluid dynamics tells us there will be a laminar boundary layer of fluid that is theoretically with a zero velocity at the wall of the tube, and then the laminar flow of the center of the column that has the assumed least amount of friction in the column.  As it moves forward, there is a viscous property that pulls the fluid behind it, from center to boundary, causing a velocity variance along the fluid plane.  Now, the two dye solutions collide, but not all the dye fluid collides all at once, the front wall of the fluid collides, then each slice of the fluid collides after it.  The fluid is dispersed in an 'an equal and opposite reaction' as that first wall collides, but then the next slice hits and the friction of the dye fluid pulls back and in some of the dispersing dye fluid before it.  This then creates a non-turbulent (i.e. laminar) rolling fluid that is progressing 90 degrees from the original vector.  As it thins AND rolls, there is an elastic separation that causes the dye fluid to react in an equal and opposite direction again (think a rubber band that was stretched outward and then suddenly released).  However, there is fluid in the space that it would occupy, so instead of filling that entire space, it creates another ring, still spinning.  I think that if you were to try to recreate this with smoke you would not get the same response because the frictional coefficients of smoke in air would not behave with the same frictional properties.   That's my best theory.

Kudos for the extraordinary effort you put into a very intriguing subject. The transition into right angle vortices is likely an effect of the Coriolis force. This is defined as the cross product of the motion of the vortex rings relative to the earth's rotation axis.
To prove that the Coriolis force is significant, the shape and/or orientation of the rings should vary, dependent upon alignment of the two fluid injectors (up/down, vs. east/west, vs. north/south)

You may think the earth's motion is insignificant. However, I've heard it asserted that grape vines tend to grow/spiral on support wires in a direction consistent with the Coriolis force and that when firefighters spray into a large fire, whether they spray in a clockwise or counterclockwise pattern will determine whether the fire is pushed away from or towards the nozzle (and again, consistent with what is predicted by computing the Coriolis force)

To me, not being a mathematician, but very analytical, the outer smaller rings make sense because the two vortexes rub against each other, eventually creating mini 90-degree offset vortexes of their own. Not very descriptive here, but I mean, this is a comment section.

Let me try explaining my theory a little better. Let's say you have two wheels in the same plane, like a car's left side. The back one turns backwards (equivalent to reverse gear), the front one turns forwards (equivalent to first gear). Now bring those wheels closer to each other, what would happen? They are rubbing against each other, and the air around them. To me, it makes sense that these two energies would dissipate into the air around them, eventually creating a 90 degree vortex above the wheels and below. Now imagine your experiment as a massive bunch of these wheels, all turning the same way, but arranged in a circle. That is why these mini vortexes appear under the right conditions.

I am not a paid, professional scientist, but I am a thinker, and I am an experimenter. I am a "scientist" in that I experiment, observe, theorize, recreate. Maybe I am wrong, but maybe I am not.

Now prove it mathematically, Mr Mathematician.

The original video was by Dr Tim Nickels, who worked with T. Lim. Tim was my PhD supervisor and an astonishing experimentalist.

The original video took him many many tries, lots of people believed it could only be seen mathematically and not in practice due primary instability mode in the vortex ring collision. He adjusted orientations slightly, emptied the tank to get rid of the dye and waited of the fluid to stabilise each time. Like you both, he was extremely patient, and deeply passionate about the beauty of fluid mechanics.

Tim died suddenly in 2010, but I can say to the authors of this video: He would've absolutely loved this, and adored your results.

Well done, you both deserve a huge amount of credit for this.

So, two things, a question, and relating what I love about science.

First, the question. Are the angles between the secondary dispersion consistent?

It doesn't seem that mysterious to me, that the secondaries form the way they do. Look at the very first shot, at 3:28. The blobs of ink are organizing into toroid shapes -- you can see the fluid rotating in response to the drag of the surrounding water, with the outer edge moving opposite to the direction of travel. The secondaries are doing the same thing, only the direction of travel is out from the center of the collision. It's not unlike the fluid dynamics of a falling rain drop, which isn't actually like the classic illustration of a "teardrop" shape, but is more like a toroid, with fluid moving around the surface, dragged by the air it's moving through.

You say that the smaller rings may be created by the low pressure zones, so that means that the high pressure zone has to move somewhere. There is already pressure coming from the direction of the actuators and the ring is moving outwards so the path of least resistance would be to move outward at a 90 degree to the ring. These rings are created when there is a relatively narrow, faster flow through the center of the ring and it drags the material (smoke, dye, air, ect.) along with it but that moves away from the inner air flow and slows down where it then is dragged back in continuing the ring, and as the narrower faster flow disperses and widens so does the ring. So if the low pressure zones are causing the material to move to one spot where the high pressure zones are moving outward then the high pressure zones would move the material with it, dragging it along, and creating a ring at a 90 degree angle.

I, like you, am fascinated with fluid dynamics. You and others may be interested in a study by NASA and the FAA in the 1980s to study vortex turbulence caused by aircraft, and the effects on other aircraft.
To me, the effects of wingtip vortices on other aircraft was a no-brainer. These effects were the focus of this study on aircraft safety, while little attention was paid to the generation and propagation of the smoke streams used to make the vortices visible.
At the time, I was involved in Unlimited Air Racing, and could usually be found at an airport, looking up. One of the usual suspects in air racing had contracted to fly his Hawker Sea Fury for the study to generate the vortices to be studied. They did this with wingtip mounted smoke generators developed by the government in secret. These were no ordinary smoke bombs nor fireworks, but used a secret formula to create the longest lasting aerial smoke trails ever seen. It reminded me of solid fuel rocket smoke. The Feds insisted on mounting and un-mounting the pods themselves behind closed doors.
As you would imagine, as the smoke streams left the wingtips the spinning vortices became immediately visible. The objective was to fly another aircraft through the vortex turbulence and to note effects on that aircraft.
Well, as happens with boys and their toys, the pilot of the smoke plane decided to fly his Hawker through some basic aerobatic maneuvers. Those of us watching have seen some of the best pilots ever to fly do these maneuvers flawlessly, but this time was different. Because of the extra dense and long hang time smoke of these generators, the spinning vortices did something incredible. As the vortices moved closer to each other, they began to unwind. Then astonishingly, the two smoke streams joined into single giant smoke rings, their diameter being equal to the wingspan of the plane.
The formation of both the vortices and development of the final rings is very much like the effects noted in your experiments.
Keep up the great video work, and stay curious!

My theory is that it has to do with surface tension and viscosity differences between the two fluids...the ink and the water. This is as much about surface chemistry as it is about fluid dynamics...both come into play.  as the two ink masses collide, the impact of the two masses causes the outward spreading of the disc, and the formation of the primary ring (fluid dynamics). But the surface tension, differences in surface energy between the to fluids, causes the ink to want to hold together for a while before osmosis takes over and disperses the ink (surface chemistry).  As the primary ring expands and thins, the ink wants to collect in on itself in a more surface energy efficient form, or a sphere.  So the outer ring breaks up and draws into smaller spheres, but the momentum towards forming a sphere causes a secondary collision, forming the secondary rings.

This is the result of two interactions: Cyclical Turbulence of the kind you see when a wing is in a stall and Circular Traffic Shockwaves. So long as the circumference is less than C, the flows remain laminar, but at C, they break into cyclically turbulent flows. C is determined by a variety of factors, primarily the dimensions of the vortex rings themselves, along with their approach velocity. At C, their laminar flows can no longer sustain themselves any more than can the airflow over a wing at distance S from the leading edge. Laminar flow becomes turbulent. On a wing, it breaks into a sort of luffing. In a light airplane, this might have a frequency of 15 Hz, but in a B-52, it feels like you're slowly driving lengthwise along railroad tracks, perhaps 5 Hz.

Reference your Making a Laminar Flow Nozzle video and see if you can more make the vortex rings more laminar, if that will increase C without adjusting any other factors.

I don’t know how many theories you have considered for the reasoning behind the horizontal rings, but here’s mine. If you watch between 6:45 and 6:55, you can see where those secondary rings start to form, caused by that low pressure you were talking about. But, what might be happening is, due to the velocity V of the original large ring forming, the air that was affected by that low pressure is still moving at that same velocity V, at a direction perpendicular to the center. So, because of the direction of the initial velocity, away from the center, and the secondary pressure, the low pressure pulling the air back in, the result is a ring, comprised of an airflow which is rotating counterclockwise, as if you were looking at a cross section of one of the the secondary rings. I’m thinking that because of newton’s third law, the pressure from the collision all has to disperse evenly, at a direction opposite the initial force. Being that the collision is happening under water, an all in one point, the most even shape it can disperse in, is a circle. Since that ring keeps moving, the resulting affected low pressure air gets forced into a swirling motion, rotating inward, also still traveling away from the center of the initial ring, forming a smaller, horizontal ring. I don’t have an idea for the number of them.....yet.

When both the rings are similar enough, the symmetry makes the flow go 90deg from the pulse. Larger things behaves very differently than smaller things in water. That's why you get the "low pressure" zones. The water "prefers" to flow in a cluster, rather than continue to become thinner and thinner, because it's the path of least resistance. The next rings are formed because the water that doesn't move outwards pulls the edges back around them.

Here's my theory behind the mini rings. I Beleive it works very similarly to those "underwater oceans" I Beleive you may have even dine a video on one yourself but, in effect there is a surface tension between the two fluids in this case the dye and the water, when the two main vortexs collide, we seem them flatten out much like a raindrop hitting a flat surface but in this case with the lack of gravity and the decreased effect of inertia due to the lack of forward acceleration of each vortex, it merely splays out flat, then surface tension and cohesion comes I to play, the center of the now disc wants to pull to the outside and vice versa but the outside is accelerating outward and thus the center part fly outward, now, with the cohesion of the dye, and the surface tension of the dye and the water, the dye remains separated mostly. As the outer portion of the dye begins to slow down the inner portion accelerating towards the ring that is forming then carries it's momentum through the now perfect ring of dye causing the ring to once again expand outwards, much like grabbing a rubber band and pulling it, eventually cohesion will break. But with the friction between the water and the dye, the dye on the outermost portion begins to slow down but the inner portion still carrying momentum and then we get the rotation we see from the vortexs and as the cohesion of the whole ring begins to fail, we see it fragment and cohesion once again forms pockets accelerating away from the center and rotating like a vortex due to the fluid friction.

I think the key to the motion is to think about conservation of momentum. That's not actually a rotation you're seeing. The overall momentum is in the same direction it always was -- pointing radially away from the center of the collision.

The dyed fluid is moving faster than the surrounding fluid, so it's at a lower pressure, so the surrounding fluid is applying an inward force on it. It's the whole reason vortex rings work in the first place. At first, the ring is able to remain coherent, but as it spreads out the pressure continues to decrease (same amount of fluid over larger area = less pressure) until the ring breaks. The low-pressure regions then collapse into spheroid bubbles -- and they're equally spaced because if they were of DIFFERENT sizes there would be a flow from the larger into the smaller to reach an equilibrium state.

And then you have spheroid bubbles moving at some velocity through a slower-moving fluid -- which is exactly the conditions for forming vortex rings!

I'm nowhere near a scientist but the only thing I could think of as to why the rings are formed is a sort of elasticity principle. Like if you hold a rubber band at both ends and pull, you get two pieces of band that are stretched next to each other (Much like the two rings at their breaking point when seen from the side) and when the tension is released it goes back to a ring shape. Because this experiment takes place under water and with the two rings colliding perfectly into each other, there is no other way to stretch but outwards. When the break happens the tension releases, all the small sections of the rings act like rubber bands and collapse back into their original state (rings). I hope I made myself understandable with this thought, could there be anything to it?

Ahh it's easy. After the low pressure zones suck the dye into their nodules, they also pull dye that was closer to the center of the disk outwards from the center. That dye/low pressure wave pushes through each nodule from 'behind' whilst also the whole thing expands outwards. It sort of gives an illusion that it all turned 90 degrees, but that's not completely the case...

The dye then expanding outwards, of course then goes around in a loop making a sort of ring... I think the number of nodules would depend on the viscosity of the dye, or even the water.

@smartereveryday I think the part that boggles you is WHY those little vortexes happen?
You forgot “resistance”.
As it pushes outward, it’s pushing AGAINST still water. Because the color water is in motion, it’s pressure is higher than the clear water it’s pushing through.
As the centrifugal form of inertia stretches the ring, the volume of the vortex gets stretched thinner. As it pushes the clear water out of the way, ...SOMETHING has to replace where the colored water WAS.

Try it with COLD colored water in HOT clear water. The BAROMETRIC “wall” between the 2 wants to partition them.
There’s your little vortexes.

the vortexs are turning, its looks like a donut moving forward, but its really that the ink is rotating (rolling) around itself like a tire, which means the inside is not moving, and the outside is moving with 2x the Vel of donut's motion forward. The front/back of the donut are moving at 1x vel. the 2x vel of each donut collides and cancels. The back of the donuts (facing towards the ink jets) are moving outwards, and push away from the center of the impact outward. The inside/collision face are pushing inwards towards the center of the donut and evacuate ink out leaving the hole. If you look at those 4 rotation vectors together (12, 3, 6, and 9 o'clock), you get the same vectors as the big donuts, just offset 90 degrees. If you could get the donuts to very slightly pass through each other and just have a near collision, I bet you'd see donuts going in to the center instead of outside.

The tertiary rings that form are probably a result of inertia. When the pressure waves collide and pancake, their kinetic energy is redirected outward. This outward motion manages to hold together for a while but eventually stretches to the point of destabilizing. That is when those low pressure zones managed to break up the secondary ring. However, that pressure wave still has energy going out at 90 degrees from the initial impact and the drag from the still, surrounding water peels back the leading edge, causing it to form those tertiary rings in the same manner as you created the first one. They are smaller and less uniform because much of the energy has been dissipated, as has much of the dye.
The key, then, is to make sure the initial impact was created between two rings of equal inertia hitting dead on. Any imbalance (more dye on one side, the angle of trajectory being off by the slightest degree, one side going off first or with greater velocity) and the whole pattern of events collapses.

I play with these in the ocean. I have a plastic coolant container with a 2.5 inch circle. They can grab air, stir up sand, startle fish, and collide with each other. Sometimes two would hit just right (one hitting the other from behind, a little offset) and a baby ring would get shot away in some direction. Sometimes they would join into a big one. They were fast, small, and powerful, so anything that happened ocurred in a fraction of a second.
I started getting into making mouth-made rings, where a released air bubble transforms itself into a huge ring. Then, I accidentally made two collide. As one approaches the other from behind, offset by the whole diameter, their edges actually suck together and make a massive, wobbly ring. There are waves going through it, and when it reaches one end, it can make it a concave shape. As like earlier, it sucks together, but now on itself. A new ring pops off in whatever direction the wave happens to be oriented. Often the rings break down in this process, but sometimes two perfectly stable (but wavy) rings (one massive [2-3 feet] and one small [~half a foot]). The big ones are very slow. You can stick your hand into one and feel it spinning for a several seconds. The small ones are feel-able, but they last for a fraction of the time of the big ones.

I have a 60 fps waterproof camera if you’d like to see it.

It looks like the first rings edge breaks into multiple sections (clumps) . The wavefronts lower pressure side helps keep the material moving outward. The action that creates the second rings is that the clumps inside high-pressure area are naturally going to the low-pressure wavefront. As these clumps are somewhat spherical at this point the resultant action is that the clumps inside moves outward from the collision area. This, in turn, makes this spherical structure turn inside out. This action of the clumps insides going outward and the edges of the clumps moving slower means once the material has distorted enough the outside will be sucked into the inside from behind these rings (closest area to collision area ). This makes it own little vortices which appear 90° rotated.

As an extra note material is still fed during and after this to behind the secondary vortices and this material is fed through the center of the vortices as well adding to the vortices rotational speed and velocity. The rotational speed helps stabilise the vortices and allows them to persist for longer rather than dissipate.

You can see these steps happen if you slow down the time and focus on one clump. I think a good follow up would be to try using different fluids other than dyed water (one that doesn't mix with water) and see how this changes the timing of different stages.

Once the collapse takes place, a rubber band effect follows at perfectly spaced intervals of which the secondary rings form. Consider each small ring as a replica of the initial collision but instead of being manually pushed by the injector, the force in each rubber band effect due to the collapse creates each one. Clearly this cause and effect can only be replicated when both inks collide at just the right speed and volume of ink.

If a vortex approaches another vortex from behind, it gets compressed, goes through the first, then the same happens to the first and they leap frog eachother when it's close enough to perfect. Not as confusing of an effect as this video, but if it were done near perfect i think they could trade places 4 or 5 times. Also, i think an explanation for this effect is that the vortex is the "shape of least resistance" for a fluid to travel through another fluid, it just requires a perfectly symmetrical "launch". The center of drag on a ball of fluid would be centered, pushing it closer to a disc and thinning the middle more than any other part, also the two inks don't fully mix, leaving more of a gap in the middle and more of an opportunity for a vortex to form. I think it's basically a complex case of "path of least resistance", and it forces the tiniest flaws to become breaking points to become the least resistant shape. I think I see how the secondaries are formed, and why the secondaries form perpendicular to the radial. When the two vortexes collide, the vortexes expand radially. At first it's 2 counter rotating vortexes that are expanding radially. As long as the vortex momentum is higher than the competing pressures, the original vortexes remain.

The 2 vortexes begin to split up into many small vortexes perpendicular to the vortex tangent. Because we're dealing with fluid dynamics we end up with one area of fluid moving outward and the other side must move slower or opposite. These tangential vortexes are counter rotating. Eventually 4 tangential vortexes collide. With a column of water where all four meet moving outward radially.

The column of outward moving fluid then creates the vortexes which are perpendicular to the radial of the original collision.

The key to the physics is the direction which the rings are rotating inwards. Lets assume that you can achieve a perfect setup with no water movement other than the rings, the rings have the same velocity (Newton's third law would have to describe the two rings basically), and that a rotating anomaly like is seen here will eventually break up when it hits a solid object. Lets also assume, that in perfect conditions, that ring, upon hitting the wall, would break up into even pieces (inertia is really the only way i know how to explain this, the ring takes the path of least resistance, therefore would break up evenly). When the ring the ends which separate from their original ring have a common rotational direction with the ends of the other ring. When the two original rings actually touch at a point, the ends rotate in the path of least water resistance, which would be the parallel, inversely rotating circumference of the other ring. The common rotational direction, inertia, and Newton's third law all imply that this could happen. It just works...

Fluid motion in water is incompressible. Water can't be compressed, so the volume of water flowing into any "Region" has to equal the volume of water flowing out.

Let me define the "Axis" as the line or direction between the two vortices. This is also the axis of rotational symmetry of the problem.

At the collision, you have a lot of water flowing in along the Axis. Looking at the collision as a Region (all the colored part is a region, for example), there is a lot of water flowing in through the axis directions. Hence, because fluid motion is incompressible, the water must also flow outwards perpendicularly to the axis. You could call it radial.

The volume of water flowing in or out of a region is the water velocity times the area of the region = A*v. Faster velocity or faster area, more volume.

Each vortex ring is quite wide, but the edge of the disk that forms is quite narrow. The water flows in through the flat part of the disk and flows out through the edges. Since volume of water flowing = A*v is conserved, when A becomes small (for the edge), v becomes large. So the water flowing outward Radially (perpendicular to Axis) is moving quite fast compared to the rings motion along the Axis.

Whenever a fluid moves sufficiently quickly relative to its surroundings, viscous friction slows down part of the fluid, it peels back and forms a vortex. The mechanism that caused the original vortices to form was an injection of fast-moving water. But now the edge of the collision is injecting fast-moving water radially in all directions. This is the simple reason why the vortices have "changed direction" or become "perpendicular" to their original state.

The motion of the water became perpendicular, because it flowed in along 1 direction, and hence must flow out along the perpendicular directions.
So the vortices became perpendicular.

Very beautiful video.

Btw the total angular momentum of a vortex is 0. You know this because each rotating ring has an opposite ring on the other side which cancels it out, but also because vortices are formed by injecting a stream of fluid without rotation.

Also btw the # of child vortices is the result of an "instability," which is powered by the perpendicular velocity of the water. So I would naively guess that a stronger vortex collision (in some sense) would affect the spacing and # of the child vortices.

Point as to why the secondary vortices are perpendicular to the initial ring.

Thinking of their motion as to directional momentum vectors, the forward face of the initial vortex ring is already perpendicular to the axis of the ring and its forward momentum, (The movement of the fluid to create the ring, spins the ring. Centre forward, outward on the face, backward on the outer, and inward on the backside.) When the two rings collide the two to face vectors complement each other doubling their momentum.

This doubling interferes with the previously balanced back-flow, and in flow, on the outside of initial ring, and the two forward momentum’s cancel each other out. The reason the backside inflows do not complement each other is because they are disrupted beforehand and do not interact with each other.

The low pressure on the collided rings, which form the secondary rings are created by streams of high pressure fluid moving out from the collision of the two rings. (Similar to the streams which created the initial rings.) Why these streams form might be due to an imbalance. As the collided rings expand, its pressure drops, and as fluids like to stick together, they pull together in streams to maintain their momentum, This stream moves through the migrated/collided ring, drawing the ink onto the interface of the stream, starting your centre forward, face out, outside backward, backside inward, moving in the direction of the fluid stream.

Please note, I’m only semi versed in momentum vectoring, and this is just conjecture. Take this into consideration when giving criticisms.

There is a reason this is so difficult. Apart from all the other variables that you have mentioned, I'm thinking that the speed of rotation at the outer edges of the primary vortices are critical. The number of secondaries produced may be the difference between the phase of the rotations, possibly with the mathematical base x.π.rad where x is the phase variance. The closer in speed the two primary vortices are rotating, the fewer secondaries are produced. This would explain why different tests show a different number of secondary vortices, and also why they are all equidistant except for one position on the point where there primaries meet - it's the remainder of function x.π.rad. The human brain seems to want to expect equidistant secondaries, or a specific number of secondaries. The juxtaposition between expectations and seeing chaos theory in action are one of the things that make this such a fascinating problem.

So... If my theory is correct, if the phase variance is 1, the angle of the secondary vortices will be 3.1415926[...]rad. It's also possible that the "seed" for the secondaries is a momentary area of high pressure, not low pressure, that transfers the energy into a secondary at right angles to the point of impact. - the rotation of the secondaries is in the same plane as the primary flow (effect of inertia), but the pressure results in the focus of the secondary moving at right angles to the impact.

As the outer ring breaks up, colored fluids packets are moving +tangent+ to the larger circle (at regular intervals ... as Destin explains a few seconds prior). These fluid packets are coming at each other at equal speeds but from opposite directions to briefly form a node. That node flattens out due to the collision to form a tiny disc. I'm far from a science degree holder but just using the eye test.. It seems to me that the secondary vortices are perpendicular to the original vortices, because the impact of the 1st vortices. Since the kinetic energies and masses of the two original vortices are about equal, it causes the residual impact energy to propagate vectors which are perpendicular to the change in vector from the original vortices. As the low pressure zones form, the perpendicular kinetic energy vectors carry on visually with the ink and form the new vortices. They form in just the same way that you create the original vortices. Just my eye test 😅

Now that you've started this idea, I say you do it again but with fluids that are non-polar. This might inhibit the ink/water from "sticking" to itself which is my theory on why the low pressure zones form. Due the the ink/water being carried away from the impact in a perpendicular vector, the amount of ink to evenly spread across that ever increasing surface area of the ink circle, decreases. Perhaps the polarity of the water and seemingly water-soluble ink, creates a threshold of diffusion. At that point, the ink/water re-coalesce, with vectors in tangent lines from the farthest point of least mass of ink/water (low pressure zones). So now there's the perfect two perpendicular vectors of inertia to create secondary vortices, along a circular path perpendicular to the original vortices.

This is amazing video and I think that the secondary vortexes can be explained fairly simply.

When the two vortexes first interact, they expend energy to expand the ring. Nature has a tendency to move all systems to the lowest energy states so there must come a point at which the energy required to maintain the expansion of the ring is greater than that of multiple smaller vortexes and the system collapses. This is analogous to the surface tension of water pulling a laminar flow into droplets.

The reason that the secondary vortexes are perpendicular to the primary vortexes is down to the conservation of momentum. This is akin to the reasons that a galaxies assume a disk like formation. For a mixture of particles with a random distribution of velocities and position, there is still an inherent axis of rotation. In the case of the secondary rings, the collapse of the primary vortex results in two relatively equal masses that are headed toward each other but are still subject to the outward momentum of the initial vortex. Their collision, being at approximately the same speed and mass results in net cancellation of motion around the initial vortex's perimeter and forces the rings outward.

The perpendicular orientation is down to gyroscopic processes. The initial vortex was expanding outward. The collapse acted as a force on a spinning object, resulting in a current turned 90 degrees, as is expected when a gyroscope is acted upon.

I might have an idea on why the ring breaks up into intervals and how new rings are generated.

As the two initial "drops" collide, the resulting pressure is spread in a disk shape, eventually focusing on the outermost ring. It gets less dense because of the ring expansion, as the same material has to cover a bigger volume. Since it's less dense than the surrounding fluids, the ring breaks up and the less dense matter focuses on almost regularly spaced points.

Now for the smaller rings. I believe that there is still some inertial flow caused by the points pulling some of the ring's length. Because of this flow going towards the point, it's like if the experiment is repeating itself recursively in a sort of fractal. The new disk/ring is "rotated in 90º" (it is perpendicular to the axis of the two coming flows), just as the first ring is perpendicular to the axis of the two emitters.

I hope it makes sense.

I suggest having a look at some literature about aircraft wake vortex pairs and the formation of linked rings. The instability mechanism is called the Crow instability - which you can often see in contrails overhead if the weather conditions are correct. The first video which shows up when you type 'Crow Instability' into youtube is a thing of beauty!

Fluid mechanically you have the same counter rotating vortex pair as you do behind an aircraft, just in a curve instead of in a straight line. This is one of many instabilities identified with a linear analysis of the wake dynamics. Crow explained the growth of disturbance waves in planes at 45 deg to the horizontal - which are the most easily identified from the ground. When these waves grow to the point of linking they have already misaligned significantly from the original direction of the vorticity. This nice linear explaination gets you 90% to the formation of the rings, and explains their size and spatial frequency - but it cant take you a neat explanation of what is going on when the vortices finally link together.

The baby rings turns don't turn 90 degrees. The two main approaching rings are rolling forward, from inside to outside. They are stable due to a kind of rotational momentum. When they meet, the pressure of the collision pushes outwards tearing the combined ring mass into equal parts, but the rotational momentum is not destroyed and each mini ring continues to roll from inside to out, self stabilizing as they go. Vortex ringlets at 90 degrees with the original vortices are formed because of the remaining radial momentum of the flow. As the vorticity of both vortices gets cancelled on each nodule the lower pressure at the interior pulls flow from each side of the nodule the inside (according to the annular/circumferential direction) leading to the cancellation of the flow momentum on the anular/circumferential direction. At this moment the vortical component of the velocity has been cancelled and the annular component of the velocity is also cancelled forming kind of a stagnation point but the flow still contains a residual momentum moving on the radial direction of the plane defined by the colliding vortices. This residual momentum of the flow forms a new vortical structure moving outwards with a plane parallel with the plane of collision of the original vortices.

Destin, first of all thank you for your beautiful and inspiring content. On the matter of what, at least, I have to overcome, unfortunately it's time. There's only a pretty set amount of time available each day for mental work before your brain turns into mush. On the other hand, you seem to be able to present a project that has been running for weeks, months and years every few weeks. What's noticeable about the way you do it is through collaborations and assignments, or to put it simply, project management. These are mini research projects and you've got lots of them running at the same time. Obviously, you can't be present in all of them at the same time, plus you have to have some time for yourself and your family, but you've quite literally set up a popular science (or should I say engineering?) research facility. So what you do is mainly setting up the projects, managing them to some extend, a bit of hands-on work and doing the brilliant dissemination for them. You work on a plan, you can secure the resources, you've got a lot of people to help you and you can deliver these awesome videos. But you can't do everything.

So, where I'm getting at is this: My (very) late grandpa used to say that man can do anything, except to squeeze juice out of a stone. I think that apart from the stone-juice (which I bet there are a million ways to prove him wrong), man can't do a lot of things, or at least, to certain degree, not all people can do all things other people can. Every personal endeavour has multiple hard constraints that can't be overcome with sheer willpower and work. But there is a silver lining. C.P. Cavafy wrote a poem called Ithaka in 1911. It was about Odysseus' voyage back home.

As you set out for Ithaka
hope the voyage is a long one,
full of adventure, full of discovery.
Laistrygonians and Cyclops,
angry Poseidon—don’t be afraid of them:
you’ll never find things like that on your way
as long as you keep your thoughts raised high,
as long as a rare excitement
stirs your spirit and your body.
Laistrygonians and Cyclops,
wild Poseidon—you won’t encounter them
unless you bring them along inside your soul,
unless your soul sets them up in front of you.

Hope the voyage is a long one.
May there be many a summer morning when,
with what pleasure, what joy,
you come into harbors seen for the first time;
may you stop at Phoenician trading stations
to buy fine things,
mother of pearl and coral, amber and ebony,
sensual perfume of every kind—
as many sensual perfumes as you can;
and may you visit many Egyptian cities
to gather stores of knowledge from their scholars.

Keep Ithaka always in your mind.
Arriving there is what you are destined for.
But do not hurry the journey at all.
Better if it lasts for years,
so you are old by the time you reach the island,
wealthy with all you have gained on the way,
not expecting Ithaka to make you rich.

Ithaka gave you the marvelous journey.
Without her you would not have set out.
She has nothing left to give you now.

And if you find her poor, Ithaka won’t have fooled you.
Wise as you will have become, so full of experience,
you will have understood by then what these Ithakas mean.

What he basically says is that the destination isn't important, but the journey towards it is, and you need to try to power through the obstacles, avoid setting them up yourself, and never lose hope. But you don't have to reach Ithaka, or any Ithaka for that matter. A failure can be a lot more glorious than many successes.

Most of us really can't do what you do, for example, we mainly don't have your charisma. Aside from the hard work, there is something to be also attributed to luck, from genetics, the home you were raised in, to a roll of a die, and that's perfectly ok. But after 20 minutes of writing this, I still don't have the time and the courage to finish all the work I have to do for this, yet another, 14-hour workday of running university research projects. Maybe I can't, but please acknowledge that this is also fine, if you've managed to at least get something useful out of it, even if you fail.

Don is right about the pressure forcing the ink/dye into discreet regions. However when the surface tension of the dye breaks the dye moves towards the center of the to be secondary ring. As it moves towards the center this linear velocity gets transformed into an angular velocity as it's moving outwards from the initial collision point. The center of mass for the secondary ring is now slowly approaching the center of the ring and the either end of the ring along its circumference is now moving towards this center of mass and it now rotates into its self. This creates a ring and also explains why the rings look like eclipses after it happens.

I have a thought on how the little vortices are formed 90 degrees to the original. The fluid from the original is being pulled in by the low pressure areas, but it's not perfectly equal in terms of mass on either side of the low pressure zone. As the two (secondary, we'll call them) "masses" collide, the disk is thrown outward, and the inequality in mass causes the rotational element to form the toroidal vortex.

Around 9 hours 37 minutes of your supercut, don't you hit upon the answer to the secondary rings with 90 degree change in the vortex? The nodule breaking up of the ring is independent of the collision, but the collision drives the ring to continually expand radially, and when the original rotating vortex ring pulls in enough material to the nodules (slowing the outer expansion of the ring), the inner part of the ring pushes through it creating the 90 degree changed vortex ring. Conservation of momentum. If both rings are perfect mirror images of each other, the spin of the new ringlets will be zero, which is what we are seeing. Ideal conditions would see the two initial rings simply stall and not grow, but one is always slightly larger than the other, and that requires expansion out to infinity. At some point, initial condition perturbation causes the singlets to firm, but if you notice, they really aren't spinning.

Starts with net zero angular momentum, ends the same as it started.

The 90 deg problem ......
I think
As the low pressure zone sucks out the fluid from high pressure zone, it gains a (relative!!) momentum .
The two sides ( which are detached from the ring) are coming against each other now. Two sides undergo a head on collision. Now they would try to go in the direction where their momentum would be conserved ( which is the direction of the main ring propagation ). So they go in the radially outward direction (of the main ring.) ( As if a bomb blast into several pieces but the centre of mass goes in the same direction)
But in going so , it creates a jet of fluid going in that direction ( radially outward). This impulsive jet of fluid creates a vortex. ( As you created with individual coloured fluid----- by a short impulsive ejection of fluid.)

When ever a jet of fluid is crated ,it creates a vortex whose plain( the vortex ring plain) is perpendicular to the jet.
So here the secondary vortex ring forms 90 deg to the main ring.

So in summary 😅
Collapse of main ring creates a set of another small jets which then create another vortex ring (s).
The direction of those ring is due to the conservation of momentum as I said before..

So here it ends😅....

Hey Dustin. I have a limited understanding of fluid mechanics but I think the reason the secondary vortices are 90 degrees relative to the two main ones is because the outter lips of the main vortices are rotating in opposite ways (just like the opposite sides of a vortex would) so you'd localy have two tubular structures rotating in opposite directions. When they break up in little vortices, these two tubes fuse together to form a vortex and since these tubes were going out along the radius of the big vortices (90 degrees), these small vortices are 90 degrees relative to the big ones.

I hope this makes sense.

I think the answer as to why this secondary rings are formed as to do with the direction the fluid rotating at the point of contact. You have slow moving particles on the outside with fast moving particles on the inside while the group is moving forwards, when the fast moving particles reaches the front edge it has to move to the outside.
Now when the both vortexes meet, they can't move forward anymore, but locally the fluid still has this dynamic of particles in the front edge moving outwards and particles in the back edge moving inwards (that can not be canceled out), this ofcourse now creates a current in the interaction (of the 2 vortexes) that naturally forms a vortex but now at a 90 degree angle.

We used a computer controlled cylinder to pump fluid behind a rubber membrane to fire toroidal vortices out of the vortex cannons.

We fixed one of the vortex cannon in a stationary position, and used a multi-axis microscope stage to align a second cannon to it… which sounds incredibly easy, until you realize that

DYE density was an experiment all on its own.
If the density of the dye mix was lighter than water, the vortex would go up.
If the dye was more dense than water the vortex would fall.

We had to overcome SO MANY VARIABLES and we basically spent about 4 hours figuring each variable.
Water/dye temperature differential
Water turbulence
Water turbidity (cloudiness or haziness of a fluid)
How to reset the aquarium
Cannon Spacing
Cannon Nozzle
Cannon Shape
Dye homogeneity in the vortex itself
The piston displacement volume
The piston stroke speed
Rubber diaphragm tension, would make one side fire faster than the other.
Water or air to drive diaphram?
Firing speed (too slow and they drift, too fast and turbulence tears apart secondaries)
We did a complete redesign of the cannon 3 different times.
The Dye loading method was changed several times
At times We tried to maintain negative pressure on the cannon chamber… we also tried to put shutters on the front of the muzzle. Ultimately I decided it was ok to live with dye dripping out of the front.

We had to premix the dyes and eventually we got there.

It got to the point where we didn’t even really know what success looked like and always thought we were there.

Hmm.. In my mind the mini vortexes are actually very easily explained. In theory. No idea how this math would work. First, let's start with the expanding ring. As it expands, it creates a low pressure zone behind it and a high pressure zone in front. The high pressure zone wants to equalize, and so (assuming an equal pressure and particle dispersion throughout the vortex) it begins to suck itself into its own low pressure zone at equidistant point.. The pressure ring begins to collapse into pressure points.. marbles of moving fluid. Now, just like letting a marble fall through water, it creates a vortex around it. This vortex creates the smaller rings. They don't visible form more smaller rings from that vortex because these smaller vortexes are not uniform enough, and possibly because there is not enough energy left in the system by this point.

I had a few thoughts and just had to get them out... The electro-chemical interactions may not be available in the purely fluid dynamics model.
Maybe you could try adjusting the pH of your fluid. My guess is high pH would strengthen the interaction because the dyes would have a heavier negative charge.
The charge on your dye molecules may be critical in controlling their interaction with each other when they collide.
Dielectric strength of your fluid comes to mind. Low dielectric (low salt) may be important since we are dealing with moving charges. It may be interesting to vary salt in the fluid.
The rotating dye molecules probably rotate in backwards circles at 90 degrees to the rings.
This is a moving charge which causes an electric current in the ring and a magnetic field, this back rotation speed might be critical.
Did you measure the distance between ringlets? These most likely are forming at nodes of positive and negative interference when the rings collide. These may turn 90 degrees to the main ring due to the direction of the electromagnetic fields formed by these moving charged dye molecules in the ringlets. These nodes form a wavelength, it might be safe to assume that it is a sound wave. From this you can get a frequency. Your smoke ring generator may need to be the right size and shape to impart a musical tone or frequency to the ring.
That's all I got. It might look really awesome with fluorescent dyes. (pretty please?)

The outward motion from collision never stops, but the places where the ink moves away from is gradually flowing towards the areas where secondary rings will form.
The motion coming from the "drained sides" gives the rotational energy, while the remaining and "focused" energy from the blast provides energy to push outwards, now with a more pointy area due to the outwards energy in the "drained" area being blocked by the sideways motion.

My vortex collision was making a 6 foot tall double reverse four bar. It was for my robotics competition this year, and it took me a full year to get it working. I had to make sure every pivot had similar friction, every motor had identical output, and every piece of metal was straight. Every time I rebuilt it, something was always off; it leaned, or it was lopsided, or it didn’t have enough passive support to let the motors lift it. Eventually got it working enough after working on the whole robot for a year. Got the Amaze award at the California State Championships.
